Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.
PRINCIPAL

Brandon, Man., Dec. 6, 1935.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith Voucher No. 35 in triplicate in favor of the Municipality of Cornwallis for $300.00 as per arrangements made through Inspector Hamilton for graveling and repairing of road through the school property. This work has been done in a satisfactory manner.

The discrepancy between the number of yards of gravel hauled and the number in the bill from the Brandon Golf and Country Club is explained by the fact that the municipality agreed to pay $30.00 and take as much gravel as they required to complete the job satisfactorily. It required 625 yards instead of 300.

I am,

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle,

J.A./W
enc. 3.

J.A. Doyle, D.D.,
Principal.
Ottawa, December 12, 1935.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 6th instant, with reference to the expenditure of $300 for graveling and repairing the road through the Brandon Indian Residential School property.

I note you request that cheque be issued in favour of the Municipality of Cornwallis. I would point out, however, that the accounts attached to the voucher have not been receipted, and, consequently, owing to present regulations, a cheque cannot be issued in favour of the Municipality of Cornwallis. I am, therefore, forwarding a voucher for your signature. You should arrange to have all the accounts receipted.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

ENG.

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.,
Principal,

Sir:

I attach hereto an excerpt from a letter received from Rev. J. A. Doyle, Principal of the Brandon Indian Residential School.

I visited the school last week and can assure the Department that the fence referred to should be renewed. Dr. Doyle has been successful in seeding to grass a large amount of this light land and we should not have further trouble with soil drifting.

The posts required will cost approximately $30. I would appreciate having authority to make the necessary purchase.

Your obedient servant,

A. G. Hamilton
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
Extract from letter from Rev. J. A. Doyle, Principal of the Brandon Indian Residential School, dated May 16th, 1936.

Following our conversation yesterday, I am writing you in connection with the fence posts required here as early as they can be secured. In moving the fence to take in more of the very sandy strip in the centre row of fields, we found a number of the posts were rotted so badly that it would be unwise to use them. Then, in our rotation of crops, we are using the north centre field, which was blown out so badly two and three years ago, as pasture. The partition fence between this field and the north-east field is so badly covered that only three strands of the wire are above ground in some places. About three-fourths of this fence will have to be pulled up and re-built. A number of these posts, in fact, the majority of them, judging by the age of the fence and the condition of the posts in the fence we have already taken up, cannot wisely be used. Further, someone set a fire on the road on the correction line, which is just north of this farm, and about twenty posts are burned off and will have to be replaced. In all, it will take 100 posts to meet our immediate needs.
Ottawa, May 21, 1936.

Dear Sir:

I have your 209-11A. U., of the 19th instant, with attached excerpt from a letter you received from the Principal of the Brandon Indian Residential School, requesting that approximately 100 fence posts be supplied. It is noted that the cost will be approximately $30.

The Department will approve of you arranging for the purchase of the posts required. It is understood that the school authorities will perform the labour in the renewing of the fence. Please forward an account, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the cost of the posts.

Yours truly,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

A. G. Hamilton, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Inspector's Office,
Winnipeg, Man.

Reverend Sir,

With reference to your letter of the 22nd instant, enclosing list of hardware supplies required at the Brandon Indian Residential School, I would point out that the majority of the articles are apparently for replacement purposes and are not supplied by the Department to any other Indian residential school in Canada. Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.
PRINCIPAL

Brandon, Man., June 16, 1937.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir:

The farm in connection with this school is situated in the Cornwallis municipality and includes Section 35 and east half of Section 28, Township 10, Range 19. The road allowance east of this property extends from the correction line for a mile and a half south, covering Section 35 and north-east quarter of Section 28 but is not open on the east side of the south-east quarter of 28. What we call the Valley Road runs between the north-east and south-east quarters of this section. The road allowance between this Valley Road and Lake Percy, which is about one third of a mile farther south, has never been fenced off. The Municipality of Cornwallis is now requesting that we give them possession of this road allowance.

I have looked up the municipal maps in the Cornwallis Municipality and they would indicate that this right of way is in the survey and it would appear as if they have a right to it. I am, therefore, writing for your direction and authority in this matter.

I am,

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle
Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.,

MUNICIPALITY OF CORNWALLIS

BRANDON, MAN., May 20, 1938

Moved by Councillor G. A. Medd

Resolution:

Second by Councillor W. Hamilton

The Council here assembled do hereby Resolve

WHEREAS- An agreement has been entered into between the Municipalities of Elton and Cornwallis for the construction of a market road on the correction line between the Townships Nineteen and Twenty; dividing the cost equally between these Municipalities; and Whereas the Municipality of Cornwallis does not receive revenue from Section Thirty-Three lying to the South of this road, therefore

BE IT RESOLVED that this Municipal Council request a grant of One Hundred and Fifty Dollars ($150.00) from the Department of Mines and Resources, Indian Affairs Branch, to cover half the cost of this mile of road construction for which we receive no revenue; the cost being Two Hundred Dollars ($200.00) for the grading, and One Hundred Dollars ($100.00) for graveling, total Three Hundred Dollars ($300.00).

This resolution was carried unanimously.

Carried A. P. Wilton Reeve
Dear Sir,

The following is extract from letter received from Dr. Doyle, together with the resolution referred to -

"The enclosed resolution is self explanatory. The agreement under negotiation between these two municipalities involves six miles of road construction, one mile of which is immediately north of our Section, Thirty three. It seems to me very reasonable that this request should be made, and we will all appreciate your good offices in making the necessary representations to the Department at Ottawa."

As pointed out by Dr. Doyle, one mile of this road is on the North side of the school property. The request for assistance to the extent of $150.00 is quite reasonable and in my opinion some assistance should be granted.

I would like to be advised as to the Departments decision in the matter.

Yours very truly,

A.G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA, Ont.

EX'D.

Ottawa,
May 28, 1938.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 23rd instant with reference to the request received from the municipality of Cornwallis for a grant of $150.00 toward the cost of a road being constructed by that municipality.

No funds for this purpose have been specifically provided and in view of the present set up of our appropriation this year it is extremely difficult to make any payment for which money has not been specially allotted. In the event of this road being constructed would it be used to any great extent by the Brandon School?

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

A. G. Hamilton, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Winnipeg, Man.
Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter 133-0-9, dated May 28th, I note that funds are not available to assist the municipality of Cornwallis in building their road.

The road is never used by the school for anything more than driving around the property to see that everything is in order. However, as the municipality has received no taxes from our land they were of the opinion that we might be in a position to make the grant suggested.

Yours very truly,

A.G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Manitoba.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA, Ont.
Dear Sir,

We quote the following letter just received from Dr. Doyle, Brandon school -

"The new grade on the road north of the School is now complete. A deputation, representing the municipalities concerned, waited on me yesterday, asking permission to get gravel out of the pit on the West boundary of the north section, and about half a mile from the north-west corner, as they wish to gravel this piece of road this fall. I told them I would write the Department in this connection.

I am of the opinion that there is plenty of gravel in that ridge to last almost indefinitely at the ordinary rate of use, but it might peter out as the bed did here just north of the school. They would like as early a reply as possible."

In May, a request was received and forwarded to the Department for assistance in building this road, which runs along the north boundary of the school property. In view of the fact that no assistance was granted and some help can be given in the way of allowing them to use gravel from the school property, I would recommend that they be allowed, free of charge, sufficient gravel to do the road lying north of the school property and any further quantity required would be paid for at the regular rate at which gravel is sold.

Yours very truly,

A.G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA
EX'D.

Ottawa,
October 14, 1938.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 8th instant with reference to an application received by the Principal of the Brandon school for gravel.

This Branch has no objection to Dr. Doyle allowing the municipality of Cornwallis, free of charge, the amount of gravel required for the road lying north of the school property.

We have rather stringent regulations regarding the sale of any Government property and consequently it is not possible to approve the sale of any of this gravel.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Ottawa,
November 14, 1938.

Reverend Sir:

A request has been received in this office to allow Mr. George Medd to take gravel from the gravel pit located on the Brandon Indian Residential School property. He states that he wishes the gravel to repair a road north west of the city of Brandon.

Last month we received a letter from Inspector Hamilton in which he advised that you had written to him recommending that the municipality of Cornwallis be allowed to get gravel out of the school gravel pit. Are you aware whether or not Mr. Medd is also applying on behalf of the municipality of Cornwallis? If so, Inspector Hamilton was advised in official letter dated October 14 that this Branch has no objection to the municipality of Cornwallis being allowed to remove gravel free of charge for the road lying north of the school property.

If Mr. Medd is not acting on behalf of the municipality of Cornwallis please let me know if you have any objection to our allowing him the permission he requests and, in this event, you might let me know what price per yard you consider should be charged.

Yours truly,

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Brandon, Man.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Ottawa,
November 14, 1938.

Brandon, Man., Nov. 22, 1938

The Secretary,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

Referring to your letter of Nov. 14, No. 122-0-9, concerning request of Mr. George Medd for gravel out of the pit located on the School property, I beg to say that I have today been able to contact the Reeve of the Municipality, Mr. Albert Wilkins, and it would appear that the request of Mr. Medd is for gravel for the road continuing westward from the northwest corner of the School property. In this connection it seems to me quite fair that the Department should allow the Cornwallis Municipality sufficient gravel for the road which has just been constructed, for the mile north of the School property, and I have no serious objection to them taking gravel for the road extending westward providing that they do not remove our fence and that they keep the pit in good workable form. The experience at this School in the past has been that neighbors or others hauling gravel from the pit have not followed along the seam of gravel at its full depth, but have taken the course of greatest convenience to satisfy their immediate need, allowing the top soil to cover a good deal of the best gravel at the bottom of the pit. If this Municipality is allowed to take the gravel, a good clear understanding of this kind should, I think, be entered into. The Reeve tells me they can secure gravel quite adjacent, at 7¢ per cubic yard, and it is my opinion that they would have no difficulty in finding gravel on a section of land immediately west of the School property, this section being owned by the Municipality itself.

I am leaving the matter entirely for your decision and will be glad to comply and give assistance to any

MEMORANDUM

6th April,

The Deputy Minister.

You referred here Dr. McGill's memorandum of the 30th ultimo in connection with the application of Mr. George Medd for permission to take gravel from the Brandon residential school property. This does not seem to cover the points raised in my memorandum of the 23rd idem and reference to the report submitted by the principal of the school on the 22nd November last does not help. One might reasonably take it from the principal's report that he had no objection to the Municipality taking the gravel free of charge. He simply mentioned that the Reeve told him they could secure gravel elsewhere at 7¢ a cubic yard. However, in the letters going out from this office we said the Department was prepared to let them take gravel at that rate.

Is 7¢ a cubic yard the usual rate charged for gravel taken from Indian property? Would the Department be prepared to authorize the taking of sufficient gravel free of charge for those portions of the road adjoining the residential school property?

Dr. McGill -

For report.

W.J.F. Pratt,
Private Secretary.
Ottawa, April 11, 1939.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER:

I have for acknowledgment Mr. Pratt's memorandum of April 6, in which he seeks additional information with respect to the charge of 7 cents a cubic yard made by this Branch for gravel taken from the gravel pit of the Brandon Residential School.

It is somewhat difficult to state exactly what the price of gravel actually is throughout the Dominion. It should be stated, however, that the price of 7 cents a cubic yard is a very nominal charge and far below the charges usually made. A representative of the Surveys and Engineering Branch states that the price frequently paid is $1.50 per cubic yard and that they have at times paid as high as $5.00. In view of the fact that the road upon which this gravel is being used adjoins the residential school, an agreement might be reached whereby the municipality would be permitted to take a certain amount of gravel without cost.

I shall be glad to communicate with Inspector Hamilton, should you consider an arrangement such as the one I have suggested advisable.

Director.

RAH.
Brandon, April 1, 1939.

Mr. J. E. Matthews, M.P.,

Dear Sir:

Received your letter this week. With regard to the road in question, the main facts are that the road built is along property belonging to the experimental farm for 1/2 mile & industrial school for 1 mile. This property does not pay taxes, therefore I think that we should receive some help by way of grant. This road will cost when gravelled (the grading is finished now) about $350.00 per mile.

The fact that Elton uses this particular road more than Cornwallis, the bulk of the payment comes from Elton. If you could get about $300, it would be quite a help as I am financing this road out of my ward appropriation.

With reference to the dugouts you mentioned, we have already contracted for about 40 in this municipality.

also, regarding Alex Poll and his being forwarded to Brandon School under police escort, I beg to advise that this boy had become unmanageable at home, wouldn't attend school and wouldn't listen to his guardian, Joyce, who when it was found that it was Alex Poll requested that he be placed in a residential school, as he couldn't do anything with him.

The first intimation I had of this case was from the police at Carnduff who informed me that he had found an Indian wandering around near Glen Even who stated his name was Billy Poll and that he was from the reserves near Broadview. I told the police that there was no Indian here by that name and that none of these Indians were away but that if he got in touch with Mr. Morrison from the White Bear Reserve near Carlyle, he could get more news. If I have any of the Indians from that reserve. Apparently there was some delay in phoning to Mr. Morrison, I believe the constable phoned to the Inspector of Police at Weyburn, who was in touch with Dr. Robertson, Inspector of Indian Affairs, Regina, the constable later phoning Mr. Morrison and when it was found it was Alex Poll of White Bear Band, told Mr. Morrison that his Inspector had told him to return the boy to White Bear. At the same time Joyce who is this boy's guardian made the request that this boy be sent to a residential school so he couldn't do anything with him at home and if he came back to the reserve he would only run away again. This information Mr. Morrison phoned to me when I got in touch with Dr. Boyle at Brandon explaining to him what the boy was like and if he could handle him I would have the police take him down to Brandon.

This boy was adopted eight years ago by Joyce No.241 of the White Bear Band and has been in treaty ever since, he has attended the White Bear Day School for five or six years and with his indifference to attending the school lately was not a good influence to the other children attending there. The past quarter he was absent fourteen days and it was very evident that he badly needed disciplinary treatment which was the large factor in my sending him to Brandon school.

Under date of Moh.15th, Dr. Boyle writes me that he is adapting himself to his new surroundings quite readily and is mixing with Stanley Lone-thunder, another White Bear boy who is at Brandon school and he does not anticipate any difficulty in obtaining this boy's loyalty to the school and a real interest in his own welfare.

Dear Sir:

A year ago last June, Vera Mallett, #0354, was, at your direction, taken to the Ninette Sanatorium. We have, of course, been keeping in touch with her ever since and received notice a few days ago that she could be returned to the school with perfect safety. Her only special treatment now is pneumo-thorax refills of 300 c.c.'s every three weeks. This, the doctors wrote us, could be given here just as well as at the Sanatorium. So we went yesterday and brought her back to the school. She has grown splendidly and has advanced satisfactorily in her school work. She will, of necessity, remain here during the holidays.

Vera's return gives us three pupils over our quota and as the department will be saving the extra cost of her care at the Sanatorium, we, of course, would be glad if you see fit to place her in a supernumerary relation to our school.

I am,

Yours respectfully,

Your letter of May 17th, #133-0-10, has just come in.

Ivan Ahenskew, #448, has taken two years in the Brandon Technical School for Automotive Mechanics. It is a three year course but of late the third year has been reduced in time. It does not commence until after Christmas holidays. Ivan would very much like to finish this course and secure his diploma and it is quite desirable that he should. If the Department does not see fit to have him continue with us for the full year I would suggest that he be given leave of absence from August 1st until January 1st and then be allowed to return to complete this course and if the school is full at Christmas that he be granted a supernumerary relation. I mention August 1st instead of July 1st as he wishes to remain during July to get more practice in the use of machinery, especially the tractor.

I am informed by Dr. Doyle, principal of the school, that Adam, Joseph and Roderick, Nos. 107, 108 and 109, attended Brandon School in 1903; then Kenneth and Norman, Nos. 173 and 174 were there in 1911; and that three girls attended school back in 1889. None of these pupils took treaty, although I understand that the mother of the children now in question was a treaty Indian and a member of the Jackhead Band. These people live at Little Bullhead on Lake Winnipeg. The mother died recently and the father is finding it impossible to look after the children.

They present their case on the ground that they themselves received this consideration and feel that now the children are deprived of their mother, similar treatment might be considered. I happen to know the uncle, Norman, who wrote in and made the request. He was a pupil at the school at the time I was there and perhaps was one of the best boys ever to attend the school.

I realize that, strictly speaking, they have no claim on the government. Dear Sir:

I have, for acknowledgment, your letter of the 9th instant, in which you refer to a communication received by you from Norman Collins, asking that his brother's children - a boy of 10 and two girls of 12 and 8, respectively - be accepted as pupils at the Brandon Indian Residential School.

You do not state in your letter the distance that these children live from an Indian day school or if they have been attending a day school until now. I cannot possibly see how the Government can permit children to enter our residential schools from this time forward, other than those children for whom we are responsible under the provisions of the Indian Act. The Indian school population is increasing at the rate of approximately 400 pupils per annum, with the result that there are large groups of Indian boys and girls in certain sections of the Dominion for whom no educational facilities whatever have yet been provided. In view of this fact and the limited appropriation at our disposal for educational purposes, I regret that I cannot approve of the admission of these children to the Brandon School. If, however, they are unable to attend an Indian day school and if they are in a destitute or semi-destitute condition, the matter may be reconsidered. I am convinced, though, that we shall have to insist on a more rigid enforcement of the regulations governing the entrance of pupils to Indian residential schools from this time onward.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Indian Education.

The Secretary, 2.

Elijah Sinclair, #444, referred to in my letter of May 4th, in yours of May 17th, #132-0-10, in mine again of May 22nd and in yours of June 1st, #132-0-10, and who was one of our brightest students, did not return as the parents needed him for work and I recommend his discharge.

Helen Cochrane, #9265, referred to in my letter of May 4th, second page, and in yours of May 17th and June 1st, was allowed to go home for holidays this year at the definite request of the agent in response to an appeal from her relatives and I learn now that her conduct while home was not good. On this account I do not feel like recommending her for domestic service in this vicinity and suggest that she be returned to her people and discharged. The prospects of her future are not good but I feel that we can render better service to some young child rather than keep her for another year.

Allan Sanderson, #475, was concealed by his mother when we went to pick up the children north of Selkirk and has not been returned. As this family is non-treaty, I think it better that he should be dropped from our list permanently.

Dora Favel, #0341, has been retained at home and given leave of absence for three years and on account of her mother's illness the agent recommends that she still remain home. I would recommend that she be discharged.

Awaiting your reply,

I am,
Yours respectfully,

J. A. [Signature]

PRINCIPAL

Brandon, Man., Sept. 24, 1937.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir:

A former pupil of this school, Clara Wabidee, of the Griswold reserve, is at present employed as a domestic in the home of Professor W. Burton Hurd, of McMaster, at 68 Whittier Road, Hamilton, Ontario, and has been giving the best of satisfaction both in her work and conduct. A neighbor of Mrs. Hurd, Mrs. G. S. Parlor, of 1212 King St., W., has written asking if it would be possible to get Clara's sister, Dora Wabidee, #0312, of this school for domestic service in her home. In my letter of May 4th, 1937, on the last page I recommended that she be continued in school for another year and in your letter of May 17th you acceded to this request. Now that this offer for employment has come, where she would be closely under her sister's influence, I would recommend that she be given the opportunity, providing the home is as suitable as would appear from Mrs. Parlour's letter. She claims to be interested in the character and general well being of those she employs and I have written Professor Hurd, whom I know personally and very favorably, for information concerning her.

Dora is probably eighteen years of age now.

Annie Flett, #0412, did not return after holidays as her mother required her services and I recommend that she be discharged.
Ottawa, October 1, 1937.

Dear Dr. Doyle:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of September 24th, in which you ask for an expression of opinion with respect to the discharge from your school of Dora Wabidee, #0312.

I am personally disposed to think that this girl should be permitted to take up domestic service, particularly in view of the fact that she will be in close contact with her sister. I am quite prepared to allow you to exercise your own judgment in dealing with this particular case.

I note your recommendation with respect to Annie Flett, #0412; Elijah Sinclair, #444; Helen Cochrane, #0265; Allan Sanderson, #475; and Dora Favel, #0341. Your recommendation that these pupils be discharged is approved.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Brandon, Man., Oct. 12, 1937.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir:

I have found the regulations that the parents, or guardians of pupils, having their children home for holidays being required to pay the fare one way is the source of a great deal of dissatisfaction, complaint and a feeling of injustice. This has come from almost all the reserves from which our pupils come and when at Hodgson this year, bringing the pupils back from holidays, a deputation of four councilmen, mostly from Fisher River, I think, waited on me with a very earnest request that the requirement be discontinued.

The arguments used in this connection are: First, that many of the parents who really should have their children home, or think they should, find it a burden, especially when there are four or five children in the same family. Then, other schools where neighbor children attend bring the pupils to the very door of the Indian home without any charge whatever.

I told this deputation that they should make representations to your Department in this connection and that I would write you, telling you of their representations to me. I might say that some of the agents have also mentioned the matter, hoping that the regulation would be discontinued or made universal with all the schools alike.

The total amount I was able to collect this year, with the help of the agents, was $97.15. A few dollars may yet come in. As the highway conditions are improving we are going to be able to use our own conveyance for this purpose more than we have been doing.
which will cut down on the actual cash expenditure on our part to some extent. And if the Department sees fit to add $50.00 to the annual grant of $300.00 made in this connection, I would be glad to take care of the other $50.00 which we collect from the parents.

We will appreciate your consideration of this matter. Awaiting your reply.

I am,

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.,
Principal.
Ottawa, October 29, 1937.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letters of October 12, with reference to the amount allowed for the transportation of children to and from the Brandon Residential School. The amount available for this service is rather limited, but in view of your special request, it has been decided to allow $350 towards transportation expenses of the Brandon school children.

I find it necessary, however, to return the account which you enclosed.

Please prepare a new account showing in detail the names of the children and their destination in each case. The exact railway fare should be stated in regard to each of them in order that the Auditor General may take no exception to the charges that are made.

It will only be necessary for you to submit an account amounting to $350.

As previously informed, all accounts should be submitted in triplicate.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

I have had a good talk with Vera Gray. I am very anxious myself that she should be given the opportunity to continue at school and we will spare no pains in getting a school for her if it is at all possible when she is through. She certainly is under no handicap as far as racial appearance is concerned.

I was very favorably impressed with the background of Agnes Kay. Her parents, while unable to talk English, seem to be a fine type of Indian, especially the father and he is anxious to have Agnes make something of herself. She is white in appearance, kindly and cordial in her attitude with others, an exceedingly pleasant manner. She was really only seventeen years of age on March 31st. She became eighteen a few days ago. She is anxious to be a nurse. She is a good student, standing third at Christmas, fourth in March, in a class of fourteen. Dear Sir:

I have delayed replying to your letter, #133-0-10, of May 12th, that I might make some further investigation in regard to Mary Tapotat, #0464, Vera Gray, #0414, and Agnes Kay, #0474.

Last Thursday I drove over to the Round Lake School to interview Mr. and Mrs. Ross in regard to all three of these girls. I was anxious to become more familiar with their background, both in regard to their homes and their attitude and application while in attendance at Round Lake.

I am unable at the present time to make any definite suggestion in regard to Mary Tapotat but would like the privilege of doing so after Mrs. Ross has written to some W.M.S. officials in the East in regard to the possibility of funds to give this girl assistance. The Rosses are unqualified in their confidence that Mary will make good if given an opportunity. It was not her wish to quit school when she did but her parents urged it and their consent for her to return to school a year ago last fall was somewhat reluctant. She has certainly made good here. Coming in just before Christmas, she covered her Grade IX work but stayed through part of the holidays a year ago to give further study to a couple of subjects on which she was weak. She is ambitious to be a nurse and manifests very decided natural qualifications for this profession. She expects to go to the Indian Hospital at Fort Qu'Appelle for the summer to earn what money she can to help with her education. I will be able to make some definite proposal in regard to her within a couple of weeks.
Ottawa,
June 3, 1938.

Reverend Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 25th ultimo with reference to Mary Tapotat, Vera Gray and Agnes Kay.

As we intimated to you in official letter of May 12 the Department doubts very much the advisability of encouraging these girls to qualify either for nurses or teachers. Mr. Hoey, Superintendent of Welfare & Training, will be in Winnipeg within the next two or three weeks and I would suggest that you get in touch with him through Mr. Hamilton's office and discuss the matter further with him.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,

The Secretary,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge your letter, No. 133-0-10, of August 29th, and regret that I have been so long in answering.

Mary Snake, or Mabel Anthony, as she appears on our books, was one of the Ontario pupils in residence here when I became Principal in 1929. She is listed as seventeen years of age, but as we advance the age of each pupil at the end of the March quarter, she may be eighteen years old now. Mabel has been a very temperamental child, a couple of years ago was very anxious to leave the School and return East, but this year she is just as anxious to stay; and her change in attitude during the past year in every respect has been very marked and very satisfactory. She is one of the very best girls at needle work that we have ever had in the School. Her embroidery and other fancy needle work has taken first prize every year in the Brandon Fair, and also at Regina; and it does not matter whether it is shown with the Indian work or in the open class. She has completed Grade X and would naturally go on to Grade XI, but we felt it decidedly better that she should turn aside from academic studies and take the course in Domestic Art provided by the Collegiate Board in the City of Brandon. She is already started on this and is liking it very much. There is no extra fee charged for this course, and the material required will cost about $15.00. At least part of this we can supply from the
Ottawa, September 22, 1938.

Re: Mary Snake, or Mabel Anthony

Dear Dr. Doyle:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 17th instant and to state that your recommendation - that the above-named girl be permitted to continue with her studies at Brandon Collegiate - is concurred in by the Department.

I note, with interest, that this girl is very capable and efficient at needle work. In view of this fact, the desirability of employing her at an Indian residential school, preferably Mount Elgin, should be seriously considered at the end of the present academic year. I am, personally, convinced that our courses of study at Indian day and residential schools must become steadily more vocational and practical in character - hence my anxiousness to have a girl such as this employed at one of our schools, even though it be on a part-time basis.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Reverend J. A. Doyle, D.D.,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Brandon, Man.

The Secretary,

Dear Sir:

I wish to write in regard to four other pupils on the Quarterly Returns, three of whom are given leave of absence, and one marked delinquent.

Q398, Leona Haywahe. Leona's sister, Gladys Haywahe, has been appointed teacher at the Sunny Valley School northwest of Dallas. It is a non-English speaking Community, the teacher must live in a teacherage. We were unable to secure a suitable older person to live with Gladys, and under the circumstances felt the best thing to do was have her sister Leona, who is now seventeen years of age, who is in Grade IX, and who is especially interested in housekeeping, to go and live with her. She is a splendid reliable girl, will likely continue the study of Grade IX with her sister, and we are suggesting that she be given leave of absence for the balance of this year and then come back and graduate with the others in June. We are getting splendid reports from these girls for the short time they have been there.

Q476, Olive Olsen. This girl took ill during the Summer, was sent to the St. Boniface Sanatorium for observation and treatment, and is therefore given leave of absence.

Q477, Gladys Olsen. This girl did not want to return to School here without her sister. The

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing herewith Quarterly Returns, which I trust will be found in order.

We have had a very serious situation arise, in the number of pupils that have not returned, and who have been kept by their parents since holidays. Statement in regard to each case is necessary. The first eighteen in the list "Discharge of Pupils" have been approved by the Department. The other fifteen, we are recommending to be discharged, some with our unqualified approval, and others somewhat reluctantly, but thinking it is the best thing to do under the circumstances. They are as follows:

0322. Mary Sinclair. Her father, Henry Sinclair, built a house on the Reserve, wanted Mary home to keep house for him. She was of age to be discharged. The Missionary and Agent both recommended it, and we decidedly approved.

0379. Sophie Williams. Mother ill, Father urged that her help was needed. The acting Agent thought it better she should remain home, and we approved.

0449. Violet Murdock. Similar circumstance in the case of this girl. The Father's request was quite urgent.

0450. Christina Murdock. This girl gave parents concern on going home for holidays, and it was mutually agreed that she get married instead of returning to School. I believe she is married now.
Sir:—

Replying to your letter 133-0-10 of the 3rd. instant, I have to advise that Elsie Joysa is 15 years of age and her Father who is Headman of White Bears Band requests her transfer.

He needs discipline badly.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:-

Referring to my letter of April 2nd 1937 when application was made to the Department for admission to the Brandon I. R. School.

Joyce the Head Man of White Bears Band married this lad's mother when he was 6 years old and the boy was subsequently taken into the White Bears Band.

In 1937 at the age of 14 years he was out of control, continually running away from home and would not stay there. He was picked up at Glen Ewing Sask by the R.C.M.P. and eventually taken at quite an expense to the Department to Brandon School.

Since he went to Brandon he has behaved himself well and the Revd. Principal under date October 15th, 1938 writes to me that Alec is a good worker and deserves great praise etc.

Joyce now states that this boy is 16 years old and he is getting old, not feeding well and wants this boy home to help him but the Revd. Principal at Brandon feels that in view of the circumstances that caused the lad to be taken to Brandon and Joyce could not manage him at 14 years of age it would be as well to keep this boy at Brandon School until he is 18 years old and possibly make a man out of him with which views I must say I concur.

The boy seems content to remain at Brandon being perfectly happy and content there.

I would be glad to have the Department's instructions in the matter.

I went personally to pick him up, but the Father refused to let him come. I took the matter up with Mr. Young, the acting agent, and he was very emphatic in his statement that Charlie was not needed at home, as there are two older boys besides the father, lying around doing nothing most of the time. They are in very poor circumstances, were on rations last winter and will be again this winter. The Agent, Mr. Young, was over a short while ago and interviewed the father, Wallace Crowe, in this connection, but without success. I wrote Wallace last week telling him that another matter of business required me to go that way this week, and I would call for Charlie, trusting that he had made up his mind not to obstruct his coming any further. Headquarters Reference to the above I beg to report that on the 17th inst., I received a letter at this detachment from Rev. J.A. DOYLE, D.D., Principal of the Brandon Indian Residential School. The following is a copy of the letter received:

Brandon, Man., Oct. 11, 1926.

Officer in Charge,
R.C.M.P. Office,
Hodgson, Manitoba.

Dear Sir,

You will no doubt receive from your Office here notice concerning a boy, Kara Wesley, who deserted from here yesterday just after dinner. He is sixteen, 5'9" in height, weighs 125 pounds, most likely wearing dark trousers, light green shirt, blue and white striped sleeveless sweater, brown zipper jacket, light cap, black overalls. His parents belong to Fisher River but are, and have been all summer, somewhere up Lake Winnipeg. It is not unlikely that the boy would endeavour to find his way to his parents and probably through Hodgson.

Four of the younger children of this family, who are enrolled here were allowed home for holidays. The parents promised to have them back when we brought the children from Hodgson about September last, but have not yet returned them. If any of your men are up the Lake and run across this family, I would appreciate it very much if you would have the parents notified that the children must be returned without delay.

It is urgent for the discipline of our School that this boy be brought back as soon as possible, and we will certainly appreciate your assistance in this connection. I am,

Yours sincerely,

J.A. DOYLE, (Signed)
Principal.

Enquiries were immediately made around Hodgson with regard to Kara WESLEY but no trace of him could be found. A patrol was made via private car from Hodgson to Halfway where I interviewed Mr. J.F. CLARKE, Indian Agent, who stated he thought the WESLEY family were up the Lake somewhere fishing but was not sure.

Enquiries were made from Indians I know who come from Fisher River and the only information I could get was that the Wesley family had not been seen since Treaty time at Fisher River. Whenever I questioned any of the Indians regarding Ezra Wesley they seemed as though they may have seen him but did not wish to say.

On the 22nd inst., a patrol was made via private car from Hodgson to Fisher River in connection with the above and other police matters and upon making enquiries around Fisher River I am satisfied that neither Ezra Wesley, nor the Wesley family, are anywhere around Fisher River or on this side of the Lake.

I happened to meet a non-Treaty Indian by the name of Willie Cochrane who lives on Matheson Island, (or Snake Island as it is called by the Indians), and Cochrane informed me that the Wesley family are at West Dog Head, just across from Snake Island. Cochrane states he is sure that the Wesley family is there, although he could not say if Ezra Wesley was with them or not.

Re: Ezra Wesley (Treaty Indian) and Wesley's Family
(Treaty Indians) Fisher River, Man., Enquiries for Indian Department.

16-1-39

1. Referring to the above, and to marginal noted reports submitted in this connection, I have to report the following:

2. When on general police patrol in the Bloodvein, East and West Doghead, Matheson Island, Birch Point, and Fisher River districts, Lake Wpgen, the 6th, 7th, 8th, and 9th insts., I made extensive enquiries, but was unable to learn the whereabouts of Ezra Wesley.

3. I interviewed this boy's parents who live at east Doghead, Lake Wpgen, and they informed me the four younger children were returned to school on October the 26th, 1938, but they have no idea where Ezra could be.

4. I later questioned different parties at Matheson Island and no person appeared to of seen this boy. Interviewing various residents in the above districts, I learned that Ezra's brother Jason is of a roving nature, usually travelling between Fisher River, Selkirk, and Kenora, Ont., and it is possible Ezra is travelling with him.

5. I then learned that Sgt. Bembridge J. was absent from Hodgson and thought it advisable to continue to Fisher River, in case Ezra had returned there. However, enquiries made did not reveal anything of this boy's whereabouts.

6. I then continued on to Hodgson, Man., where I later interviewed Sgt. Bembridge J., who informed me he was positive Wesley was not in the Fisher River district.

7. In view of the foregoing this file will be closed at this detachment for the present, and if Ezra Wesley is located the necessary action will be taken and a further report submitted.

8. Please may I respectfully suggest that copies of this report be forwarded to the Selkirk and Kenora detachments as it is possible someone may know of one of the above lads passing through the district.

CONCLUDED at Berens River.

Sgt. Bembridge Investigator
At Selkirk and Kenora Det.

19-1-39.

1. Reference to the above and forwarding minute of G.C.Wpg.Sub-Div., dated 15-1-39. At 1.30 P.M., above date, acting on instructions from N.C.G. L/C Kenora Detachment, I left Detachment and travelled by private auto to the Cecilia Jaffreton and Stanley's Indian Schools and interviewed a number of the older pupils who might have seen the above mentioned Ezra Wesley had he been in this district. None of the boys interviewed could tell me anything concerning him and did not know the brother, James Wesley. The Principals of the Schools had never heard of them and never knew of them visiting their Schools.

2. Capt. F. Edwards, Indian Agent was interviewed in this connection and stated that he had never heard of the Wesley's being in this district. Rev. H. Sanderson, Church of England missionary who travels all over this district also stated that he had never met them here.

3. As it was felt that had the boys been around Kenora they would very likely have gone out to the Rat Portage Reserve, I patrolled to that point by private auto in the same P.M. and questioned the Indians there but could learn nothing. The Indians all promised that should they discover any trace of Ezra Wesley they would notify this Detachment immediately.

4. Patrol returned to Detachment at 4.00 P.M. same date.

Headquarters:

Detachment:

I beg to report that enquiries have been made while on patrol in connection with other police duties, by members of the Selkirk Detachment. Enquiries were also made at the Olandebege Agency, Department of Indian Affairs Selkirk and the Agent, Mr. E. Pearson stated that he would make enquiries at the Brokenhead and Ft Alexander Indian Reserves, such times as he had to go there in connection with his duties.

P.C.R.

Indians from the said two Indian Reserves have been questioned by members of this detachment, when coming in this building to see the Indian Agent, as this office and the Department of Indian Affairs are in the same building.

To date no person has been located that knows the above noted Ezra Wesley and no useful information has been obtained as to his present whereabouts.

A description of this missing boy is being kept on file at this office, and the matter will be kept in mind, and the necessary action taken should any useful information come to hand, in the meantime the file will be considered closed, unless instructions are received to the contrary.

I may state that early in October last, the Matron of the Indian Residential School, Brandon, was here and assisted by Mr. Pearson, Indian Agent, Selkirk, tried to locate this Indian boy in this district, and at that time no useful information was obtainable.

The following we recommend to receive honourable discharge and graduate in the regular way:

No. 0287 Mabel Anthony, Age 18.
This girl has improved very much during the past year, has attended Brandon Collegiate, taking Domestic Art, and has done well. She is exceptional in needlework, and we hope work can be found for her where this outstanding talent can be used to the best advantage. She comes from Ontario.

No. 0438 Lavina Bear, Age 18.
Partly on account of illness during 1937-38, Lavina did not pass her Grade XI examination and has taken the year over this year, but as she has not made up her mind to qualify for any special line of work I do not think she should be continued in School and would recommend that she graduate this year.

Of those just mentioned apparently 9 have expressed a desire to receive training either as a nurse or a teacher. This would involve considerable additional education with consequent expense. Having in mind the number of qualified white nurses and teachers who find it difficult to obtain employment and the further fact that it is even harder for Indian young people, even though trained, to obtain employment the Department hesitates making an immediate decision as to whether they should proceed or be discharged. With this in mind I should appreciate your again considering these cases and letting me have your view.

Russell MALLET (Indian) missing from Indian Residential School, Brandon, Man.

(1) Reference C.M., "D" Div., 80-39 in respect to the above, I beg to report that on Sunday, April 23rd last, I received a telephone call from Regent to the effect that the above named Indian boy had been seen in the District, that at 5 p.m., he had enquired the direction around the West end of Whitewater Lake and was directed 4 miles West Regent and then South. Time of phone call, 3:05 p.m. At 3:10 p.m., I left Deloraine via pol.Cam. #1796 and proceeded to Regent and Dist., where a search for the boy was made, but without success. Search being continued until 8:45 p.m.

(2) There was no official instructions regarding MALLET, but information as to his whereabouts was passed on to me as the result of a radio broadcast. There is no doubt that the Indian boy at Regent was MALLET, information examined the clothing of the boy and found the No.54, his general description also tallied.

(3) MALLET was next seen on April 26th in the Deloraine Dist., S.E. when search was continued with Town Cst. W.P. ROSENREDER, also without success. Subject continued to head South, avoiding main roads and travelling on foot. All farmers in the Dist. were advised regarding MALLET, but no further information of value was gained.

(4) Other duties interfered with continued search. There is little doubt that the above named was heading for the U.S.A. and would likely travel to the U.S. Indian Reserve near Dunseith N.D. USA. On 25/4/39, the U.S. Customs and Immigration patrols were advised to keep a lookout for MALLET and advise this Det., of any results, to date none are forthcoming.

(5) On 5/5/39, whilst at Bottineau N.D. on other duties, I requested OPL. E.A. SIMMONS, of Dunseith N.D. (Customs Patrol) to make definite enquiries at the U.S. Indian Reserve near Dunseith regarding the whereabouts of MALLET, at the same time supplying him (Simmons) with a description of subject as per "D" Div., C.M., 80-39. Dear Sir:

I wish to thank you for your letter of May 22 No. 133-0-10, concerning graduates and other senior pupils in connection with this School.

I appreciate very much that Alma Cree, No. 0288, is allowed to remain in the School for another year. We will certainly do our best this year to find a suitable place for her.

In the lists you submit, there are four names omitted: No. 0284, Irene Black, page 2 of my letter of May 12; No. 0476, Olive Olson, page 3; 449, Charles Crow, page 3; 447, Samuel Wabideeska, page 5. Take it that these have been omitted from the list of those which should be discharged, and I will regard them as belonging to this list unless I have further word from you and will be glad if you will forward in due time Diplomas of Discharge for all of these except Gladys Olson, who is only thirteen years of age,—her number is 0477; and Ezra Wesley, 377, who truanted from the School last fall.

In regard to the eleven names of pupils set apart for further consideration, I have taken up each case with the individuals themselves, penetrating as well as I could into their own ambitions and desires, and willingness to sacrifice if need be, to achieve their purposes; have also talked each case over with their teacher and other members of the Staff who are most familiar with their attitude, spirit, and the type of work they do; and will review each case in detail. Before reviewing these cases I wish to say that I very definitely agree with you in the belief that we should work into a variety of very practical courses for both boys and girls, and turn as many as seems wise of our pupils into these courses; at the same time leaving the way open for those who have the ability and a real burning ambition to take up higher educa-

tion and qualify themselves for the very highest form or type of work and service of which they are capable. I think only a very few should be encouraged to qualify as teachers, but with the girls I feel there are a large number who could qualify, and would qualify, as Nurses, and would be exceedingly proficient in that profession. The experience with Rosabelle Ryder, who is now completing her second year in St. Boniface Hospital, is very encouraging. Rosabelle had to study hard to get up her work in School, but she did have that burning ambition, of which I speak, to be a Nurse; and while she was not as promising as many other girls, we felt confident that this ambition would carry her a long way, and I can say now with confidence, that I have never had reports in regard to anyone taking this or similar training that have been more satisfactory and consistently fragrant with praise. The Sisters whom I have consulted in the Hospital have been unqualified in their commendation of Rosabelle's attitude, efficiency, and general deportment. I have the impression also that graduate nurses could be employed in connection with our Indian Hospitals, Residential Schools, and even to some extent on the Reserves, to very great advantage. We have now adopted the policy of having a trained Nurse on our Staff, and when a vacancy occurs I would have no hesitation in taking one of these girls, after she had received her training. In fact I am now making it a policy to keep one graduate employed on our Staff regularly. We have had as many as three at one time, but this does not work to as good advantage as having one or possibly two.

Our graduates who have gone through as teachers have given us splendid satisfaction. Four of them are teaching this year, and the reports in each case are splendid. Lulu Ironstar taught for nearly three years. She is now married, living at Nelson House, and is keeping a good home. The same can be said of Winnie Steinhauer, who taught for about five years, then married in northern Alberta; and these girls are certainly better housekeepers and better homemakers on account of the training and experience which they have had. The same thing would apply in regard to nursing. If a girl who is adapted to it took a Nurse's training and then married a progressive type of Indian young man, and lived on the Reserve, she ought to be a very valuable acquisition for the betterment of conditions on the
We have already made some start on the more practical courses to which I have referred, along the line of domestic art. The course in plain sewing, dressmaking, and fancy needlework, on which we have made a commencement, has given us good satisfaction. The work we exhibit at the Brandon, Regina, and Prince Albert Fairs has brought us satisfactory prizes. Then, as you know we have had Mabel Anthony attending the School for Domestic Art in Brandon and I had a talk with the lady directing this work this morning. She was exceedingly well pleased with Mabel's work. I asked her where she would place her as to standing in her class of over forty. She said she could not say without going over her list carefully, but that she was easily in the first ten in the class. I have a feeling that as many girls as possible should be given this training and then a few of the more talented and ambitious girls singled out for special training with a view of them getting employment along this line. I feel also that there should be a certificate or diploma given in this branch as well as a number of others which I will mention later.

Apart from the practical training that every girl gets in the kitchen and dining room, we have been giving a number of them special lessons in the art of cooking, and some instruction in food values, balanced menus, and such like. I think that this course should be enlarged and those that attain proficiency and pass a written examination on dietetics should also receive a special certificate or diploma.

Our course in home nursing, under the auspices of the St. John's Ambulance, has been exceedingly helpful and satisfactory. We endeavour to have ten to about fourteen girls take this course each year. The trained nurse on the Staff is able to give the instruction, the girls take to it very readily, and a Doctor and Nurse from the City are appointed to conduct the examinations, and the diploma they receive is an added incentive for them to take this course, and it certainly has given the girls more confidence in themselves and made them much more useful and helpful in the dispensary and hospital wards when there is sickness.
I feel also that it is very important that these practical courses, followed by examination and the granting of diplomas, should be put on for the boys. We have already made a start in Automotive Mechanics, in having a few boys each year attend the Technical School for this purpose, in Brandon. On the whole we are well pleased with the results. At least two of our boys have distinguished themselves in handling tractors, and others have secured employment more readily and proven themselves more efficient on account of taking this course.

We now have a man on the staff, Mr. Clarence Zee-land, who has taken the Diploma Course in connection with the Agricultural College. He was with us last summer and returned this year after completing his course; and we are in a position to put on, or at least to make a start, in some other courses we have in mind. There should be one course, I think, in Field Crops, including everything in the line of grain and fodder; then under Horticulture, the cultivating of all garden produce, shrubs, fruit trees, etc.; under Stockraising, types and breeds, feeds and feeding should be taken up. Then I think there should be a separate course for Poultry, and a fifth one for Dairying, including Bacteriology; and now with the acquisition of the bees which we have secured, a course on Beekeeping. Later I hope that a course could be put on in Fur Farming. This makes seven courses under the general head of Agriculture, and I feel that there should be a diploma or a certificate of standing granted to each boy who responds well in the practical side and passes a written examination on the material given. Being situated right here by the Experimental Farm, we could get very valuable help in connection with these courses. We already avail ourselves of the opportunity of sending a group of our boys to the ten-day short course which is given in Brandon in connection with the Experimental Farm, just previous to and part of the time of the Winter Fair. I think also there should be taken up here, and perhaps in most Schools, a course on Woodwork, Handicrafts of different types, and Instruction in Building Construction. This, of course would have to be somewhat elementary, but many of our boys would take to it readily, and a diploma should be granted for this
also after satisfactory examination had been passed. I have a feeling that the Department would like to, with the aid of the Agricultural Department at Ottawa, lay out some practical courses along these lines, which we could take. So many pamphlets are now produced, that it seems to me, courses could be outlined very readily and without much expense.

I do think it would give the boys a greater desire to go ahead and make something of themselves, and greater confidence in their ability, if they were able to secure a number of these diplomas before they finish their work in the School. With most of them it would mean that their academic training would perhaps not go beyond Grade VII; some of the brighter ones would be in Grade VIII; but I do not think their entrance to these classes should depend either on the Grade they are in, or on their age, so much as their natural aptitude, and general I.Q.

Now, as to the individual cases in the list of eleven on page 2 of your letter. No. 0351, Oriel Flett.

This girl has made such decided improvement, and now seems so determined to go ahead and train as a nurse, that I would very much like to see her have the opportunity. There is almost no sign of the Indian about her, none of that shyness or backwardness that handicaps so many of our pupils, and she is just seventeen years of age.

No. 0386, Doris Ironstar

She is a sister of Lulu, who took a teacher's course and did well as a teacher and now keeps a good home. She is a wholesome, frank, honest, go-ahead type, inspires confidence, and should do well as a nurse, and will be glad if she is given the opportunity of going on.
This girl is the third sister we have had of William Bear's children. They are certainly a family with more than ordinary ability. In my talk with her last evening she revealed that church work of some form is in the back of her head, and would like very much another year in School to be qualified suitably to take any additional course that might help her toward the desired end. She is attractive in appearance, would pass for a white girl anywhere, and has the ability to succeed.

No. 0397, Elizabeth Haywahe. Elizabeth will be greatly disappointed if she has to turn aside to some other course. She has lots of driving power, will give up anything for her studies, is so wholesome, straightforward, and ambitious, that I dislike very much to see her turned aside. I know however she will have a real struggle to make the academic standing necessary to train as a nurse. She would like to have a talk with Gladys, and Leona, her twin sister, before making a final decision. I would like to see the way left open for her.

No. 0414, Vera Gray. With the new regulation that students must have an average of 60% on the four English subjects, and an average of 55% on all the other subjects of Grade XII, before being admitted to Normal School, it is just doubtful if Vera can qualify for Normal School next fall. If she reaches this standing I certainly think she should be allowed to take Normal next year. If she does not, I feel it is asking the

Dear Sir: Attention Mr. Phillip Phelan

I am in receipt of your letter 133-0-10 of June 21st concerning the discharge of Mary Anthony, 20 year old pupil of the Brandon Indian Residential School whose mother Mrs. Eli Snake of the Muncey Band of this agency has been requesting her discharge.

As Mary Anthony is a member of the Moravian Reserve, I would consider it best that she would live with her sister Mrs. Bert Noah at Thamesville, Ont., where she would be in close proximity to Chatham, where a girl of her ability could procure employment.

I would not be in favour of this pupil taking up permanent residence on the Muncey Reserve but there would be nothing to prevent Mary visiting her mother here for short periods at a time if she sees fit.

Concerning the notation of the Principal of the Brandon School that Mary took a Domestic Arts Course I would advise that the Rev. Principal of Mount Elgin School informs me that he has no vacancy in the sewing room in his school at the present time and is at present carrying Miss Bunice LaForce as an extra on his staff.

CANADA

INSPECTOR'S OFFICE

EB WINNIPEG, MAN., January 14th, 1936.

Attention of Mr. Sutherland

Dear Sir:

I wish to acknowledge receipt of Department Letter 123-0-10 dated December 12th, 1935, and enclosure.

I have just returned from the Brandon Indian Residential School and wish to submit the following report.

As to the children not receiving enough to eat, I enclose the menu, which is carefully followed. I noted the senior children could have all the bread they desired and all the pupils were supplied with a good helping of vegetables and meat. None left the table hungry.

This year the root house is filled with potatoes; in fact, the quantity cannot be used for school purposes and at least a carload will be sold. There is also a good supply of cabbage, beets and parsnips. The carrots were diseased and did not keep. The turnips all went to neck, but a supply is being obtained from a neighbour.

Since September 24th, nineteen head of cattle have been butchered; these averaged 1180 lbs. and dressed out to an average of 610 lbs. Dr. Doyle has a quantity of this meat in the ice house and there are six head yet to kill. A carcass is used every two weeks.

The Chovin children came to Brandon School in January, 1928, while I was on the staff. Frank was 5, Mary Louise 4, and Charlie 2. Frank was discharged last summer; Mary Louise is close to 17 and weighs 120 lbs., a fine healthy girl. Charlie is around 16 and weighs 110 lbs. Both are in good health.

The boys who stole had both been discharged; in fact, one was from Elkhorn, although previously in Brandon. Freddie Omen was the Brandon school boy and David Small the Elkhorn boy. They were both discharged and working out at the time. Last summer, four small boys, aged 9, 11, 12 & 14, went into Eaton's and stole some candy, toys, and sugar. The matter was brought to Dr. Doyle's attention by Mr. Hunter, of the Y.M.C.A. Dr. Doyle immediately found out all the particulars,

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
gave the boys money to settle for the goods, and
accompanied them to make sure the matter was adjusted.
He then punished the boys by making them work on Saturday
afternoons and holidays until the value of the money had
been refunded. He has had no further trouble and the
incident certainly was not brought about by hunger.

Dr. Doyle does occasionally use the strap if
he considers such punishment necessary. He emphatically
states that he has never hit a boy with his fist.

Dr. Doyle states Frank was discharged in good
health, but that he was not as robust as the other
children. The boy who went north six weeks ago was Sammy
Foster. He was discharged in September, 1932. He worked
for a farmer west of the school and gave good service.
He visited the school a few days before leaving for the
north and left on December 2nd for Thicket Portage. On
leaving, he came to the school office and thanked Dr.
Doyle for his kindness and incidentally remarked that the
spirit of the school was the best he had known. Later,
he sent a Christmas card to Dr. Doyle and the pupils.
I know Sammy well. He is slight in stature, but healthy.

The children are all well clothed. The mother
has sent clothing, especially the last two years; in
fact, she does everything in her power to make the
children dissatisfied. Her donations of clothing are
not essential to the children's comfort.

The children have not been allowed home,
because the distance was too great and the mother had
no intention of allowing them to return. Another reason
was on account of the mother's conduct while in Brandon.

I have covered the complaints and now wish to
set forth other particulars which will no doubt supply
the motive for these complaints.

The three children were left at school in 1928
by Mr. & Mrs. Chovin. This couple parted and I do not
know whether Chovin obtained a divorce or not. He now
lives in St. Paul, U.S.A. Mrs. Chovin apparently became
Mrs. Perger. Perger works on the railroad north of The
Pas and no doubt makes a fair living. Almost ten years
after leaving her children, Mrs. Perger wrote asking if
they were at Brandon or Edmonton and asked for information
concerning them. In 1933, she and Perger came to Brandon
and took a room for one month. They called at the school
and may have had a meal or two there, but usually took
the children to town Saturday afternoon. The husband
returned north, leaving his wife. She called several
times in a big taxi, and eventually was arrested in a
house on the flats. The house is known as "Old Pete's"
and is reported to be a rendezvous for loose women,
especially Indians. She resisted arrest and was taken
to the Mental Hospital. She sent for Dr. Doyle and
requested him to get her clothing etc. from Pete's
house. The police went with Dr. Doyle and secured her
belongings.
belongings. She had contracted debts and Dr. Doyle wrote her husband for money to pay the bills and send her home. Dr. Doyle felt he could not depend on her to leave the City, so drove her, in company with a matron, to Neepawa where he put her on the train. Within a short time, she was arrested in The Pas and brought back to the Mental Hospital at Brandon with a black eye and other bruises. The hospital authorities refused to release her until Perger appeared in person. He came several weeks later. Together, they taxied to the school, saw the children for a few minutes at breakfast, and then left for the train. The children have never been informed concerning any of this and only know the best side.

Perger claims to have a homestead near Edmonton and stated the boys would be of great help.

I am familiar with the whole situation and would recommend that both Mary and Charlie be retained until they are 18 yrs. of age. The lack of interest during the first ten years hardly justifies their deep interest now - the boys and Mary have now reached a useful age. Undoubtedly, Mary is much better off in school than any place else.

I trust my report covers the whole situation. However, in closing, I would draw the Department's attention to the Provincial School Inspector's report dated December 2nd, 1935. This is the opinion of an outsider and one well qualified to express his views.

Dr. Doyle granted me the freedom of the school and stated I was free to talk to any of the children or staff.

I trust my recommendation that Charlie and Mary remain at school will be approved. Mrs. Perger's letter is returned herewith.

Your obedient servant,

A. G. Hamilton
Inspector of Indian Agencies

Nov 18/35

I am writing this letter in regards to the Brandon In. Res School and also about the treatment of the school. Mr. J. B. Doyle, it is the way the children are treated, these children don't get enough to eat their plates of food for them all, lots of meat and vegetables, vegetables are thrown away in the fall, instead of canning them for winter use.

The boys are getting in jail for stealing, one boy done a month, and some more boys done some shoplifting at T. Eaton store in Brandon. They took food because they were hungry. These things never happen before, about children going out to steal food to fill their empty bellies. I know Mr. Simmons before Mr. Ferrier, who was principal, before Doyle and I knew them well, and about the punishment at school, these children are afraid to say anything, about not getting enough to eat, they are scared of Mr. Doyle, because he strips them to clothes, also makes his fists to the boys, I don't think this thing should be allowed, it would be very nice to ask these children at school, while they are there, they are scared of Mr. Doyle, Mr. Doyle should deny anything I say in this letter. I will be there this spring about March, I seen things in that school that would make your heart sick. Mr. Doyle has the Big Paw in front of him, at half past...
the Big Boys has to drive team ten miles and to see the clothes that they have to wear. It's a shame what you see in that school, who gets the thanks to the principal, and it's the boys that look after stock and garden, and what. Sure enough they have a man over them. I can prove all I say is true. I have a boy who was at Brandon school; that boy was not fit to do a real man's work. He was too weak, if you would let clay, with some beef up to bone, be a real man, and another boy came from there six weeks ago. He was in the same condition, where he did not have much life in him. Everybody around here seem how my boy was when he came home, and to see him now after three months' home, he working to clay doing a real man's job. I've been in Brandon school writing, my husband and myself, and she seen plainly, and what a person sees with their own eyes is the truth. I know my husband could not forget, show the children our feet, when they go to the table they just swallow their food. I buy clothing for my children out of my own pockets, to give them clothes & shoes this season for the winter. I asked Mr. Doyle to let me have my children for summer holidays. He wrote and told me about him unwilling to allow about $15, and said I could not have them. I send a pass for them to come, so he told me. I had to pray their face I am in the position to pay the fare. He made me pray.
for my boys fare, when we came home for good
and the Indian agent told me to go to the
school to pay their fare when they go home for
good. I have letters to show for this; he lets
other children go home for summer holidays
but I can't get mine. Mr. Doyle is training the
children to be thieves, and she doesn't know it.
He gets plenty to eat for himself
therefore has no feeling for others. I want my
other children to stay there till they are of age.
but I would like to have them come some times
if nothing can be done I shall have to take my
children out of the school. It can be done
when every thing is told.

I am yours truly,

Mrs Geo Burgess.
