WINNIPEG, MAN., January 14th, 1936.

Attention of Mr. Sutherland

Dear Sir:

I wish to acknowledge receipt of Department Letter 133-0-10 dated December 12th, 1935, and enclosure.

I have just returned from the Brandon Indian Residential School and wish to submit the following report.

As to the children not receiving enough to eat, I enclose the menu, which is carefully followed. I noted the senior children could have all the bread they desired and all the pupils were supplied with a good helping of vegetables and meat. None left the table hungry.

This year the root house is filled with potatoes; in fact, the quantity cannot be used for school purposes and at least a carload will be sold. There is also a good supply of cabbage, beets and parsnips. The carrots were diseased and did not keep. The turnips all went to neck, but a supply is being obtained from a neighbour.

Since September 24th, nineteen head of cattle have been butchered; these averaged 1180 lbs. and dressed out to an average of 610 lbs. Dr. Doyle has a quantity of this meat in the ice house and there are six head yet to kill. A carcass is used every two weeks.

The Chovin children came to Brandon School in January, 1923, while I was on the staff. Frank was 5, Mary Louise 4, and Charlie 2. Frank was discharged last summer; Mary Louise is close to 17 and weighs 120 lbs., a fine healthy girl. Charlie is around 16 and weighs 110 lbs. Both are in good health.

The boys who stole had both been discharged; in fact, one was from Elkhorn, although previously in Brandon. Freddie Omen was the Brandon school boy and David Small the Elkhorn boy. They were both discharged and working out at the time. Last summer, four small boys, aged 9, 11, 12 & 14, went into Eaton's and stole some candy, toys, and sugar. The matter was brought to Dr. Doyle's attention by Mr. Hunter, of the Y.M.C.A. Dr. Doyle immediately found out all the particulars.

The Secretary,

Dept. of Indian Affairs,

OTTAWA.
gave the boys money to settle for the goods, and
accompanied them to make sure the matter was adjusted.
He then punished the boys by making them work on Saturday
afternoons and holidays until the value of the money had
been refunded. He has had no further trouble and the
incident certainly was not brought about by hunger.

Dr. Doyle does occasionally use the strap if
he considers such punishment necessary. He emphatically
states that he has never hit a boy with his fist.

Dr. Doyle states Frank was discharged in good
health, but that he was not as robust as the other
children. The boy who went north six weeks ago was Sammy
Foster. He was discharged in September, 1932. He worked
for a farmer west of the school and gave good service.
He visited the school a few days before leaving for the
north and left on December 2nd for Thicket Portage. On
leaving, he came to the school office and thanked Dr.
Doyle for his kindness and incidentally remarked that the
spirit of the school was the best he had known. Later,
he sent a Christmas card to Dr. Doyle and the pupils.
I know Sammy well. He is slight in stature, but healthy.

The children are all well clothed. The mother
has sent clothing, especially the last two years; in
fact, she does everything in her power to make the
children dissatisfied. Her donations of clothing are
not essential to the children's comfort.

The children have not been allowed home,
because the distance was too great and the mother had
no intention of allowing them to return. Another reason
was on account of the mother's conduct while in Brandon.

I have covered the complaints and now wish to
set forth other particulars which will no doubt supply
the motive for these complaints.

The three children were left at school in 1925
by Mr. & Mrs. Chovin. This couple parted and I do not
know whether Chovin obtained a divorce or not. He now
lives in St. Paul, U.S.A. Mrs. Chovin apparently became
Mrs. Perger. Perger works on the railroad north of The
Pas and no doubt makes a fair living. Almost ten years
after leaving her children, Mrs. Perger wrote asking if
they were at Brandon or Edmonton and asked for information
concerning them. In 1933, she and Perger came to Brandon
and took a room for one month. They called at the school
and may have had a meal there too, but usually took
the children to town Saturday afternoon. The husband
returned north, leaving his wife. She called several
times in taxi and eventually was arrested in a
house on the flats. The house is known as "Old Pete's"
and is reported to be a rendezvous for loose women,
especially Indians. She resisted arrest and was taken
to the Mental Hospital. She sent for Dr. Doyle and
requested him to get her clothing etc. from Pete's
house. The police went with Dr. Doyle and secured her
belongings.
belongings. She had contracted debts and Dr. Doyle wrote her husband for money to pay the bills and send her home. Dr. Doyle felt he could not depend on her to leave the City, so drove her, in company with a matron, to Neepawa where he put her on the train. Within a short time she was arrested in The Pas and brought back to the Mental Hospital at Brandon with a black eye and other bruises. The hospital authorities refused to release her until Perger appeared in person. He came several weeks later. Together, they taxied to the school, saw the children for a few minutes at breakfast, and then left for the train. The children have never been informed concerning any of this and only know the best side.

Perger claims to have a homestead near Edmonton and stated the boys would be of great help.

I am familiar with the whole situation and would recommend that both Mary and Charlie be retained until they are 18 yrs. of age. The lack of interest during the first ten years hardly justifies their deep interest now - the boys and Mary have now reached a useful age. Undoubtedly, Mary is much better off in school than any place else.

I trust my report covers the whole situation. However, in closing, I would draw the Department's attention to the Provincial School Inspector's report dated December 2nd, 1935. This is the opinion of an outsider and one well qualified to express his views.

Dr. Doyle granted me the freedom of the school and stated I was free to talk to any of the children or staff.

I trust my recommendation that Charlie and Mary remain at school will be approved. Mrs. Perger's letter is returned herewith.

Your obedient servant,

A. G. Hamilton

Mrs. SMITH is an aunt of the above named Stanley SINCLAIR. On my arrival there I interviewed Mrs. SMITH in this connection. She informed me that she had not seen her nephew SINCLAIR for about seven years and that he had never been at her place at St Peters. I then informed Mrs. SMITH about this boy's escape from the Indian Residential School at Brandon, Man., and requested her to notify this office should this boy come to her place. Mrs. SMITH promised that she would do as requested and I am satisfied that she will do so.

(3).
On my return to Selkirk I interviewed Mrs. Frank SHAD, 117 Farin Ave., Selkirk, Man., and Mrs. Sam JOHNSON, Clunyboy Ave., Selkirk, Man., as the above named is a nephew of both these women. They both stated that they had not seen Stanley SINCLAIR for several years and that he had never been to their places at Selkirk. I informed them of this boy's escape from the Indian Residential School, at Brandon, Man., and requested them to notify this office should they receive any information in regard to this boy's whereabouts. Both Mrs. SHAD and Mrs. JOHNSON stated they would do as requested and I am satisfied they will do so. Further enquiries will be made in this connection in this district and reports submitted.

This boy in company with other boys from the school had come into the city to attend church at about 11:00 a.m. and it is learned from the others upon their arrival back at the school that SINCLAIR had not attended church but had said something to the others about beating it away.

2. The description of this Indian boy follows:

Stanley Sinclair, 17 years old, undersized for age, thin face and pointed chin, very shy and reserved, wearing dark cap, white shirt, collar and tie, dark suit, no overcoat.

3. Upon receiving this complaint the writer patrolled as far east as Douglas on No.1 highway in Police Car Code #2296, accompanied by Sergt. Mitchell of this Detachment. Enquiries were made at Douglas and along the road but no one had seen SINCLAIR either on the highway or on the railway tracks.

4. Brandon City Police were notified and given a description of the missing boy. Portage La Prairie Detachment were communicated with by telephone and instructed to watch the highway and the trains moving east in an endeavour to locate this boy.

5. Dr Doyle telephoned this office this date to say Stanley SINCLAIR has an aunt living four or five miles out in the St. Peters Reserve, Selkirk, and her name is Lizzie SMITH. He was thinking Stanley might try to reach his aunt and stay there for awhile.

6. I would respectfully request that further enquiries in this connection be made by Selkirk and Hodgson Detachments.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of April 8th, No. 133-0-10, concerning Stanley Sinclair, No. 379, and in reply wish to say that we have this boy in the list of those we intended to recommend for discharge at the end of this academic year.

When Stanley ran away, Inspector Hamilton happened to be here. I talked the matter over with him and he suggested that Stanley be kept in the school till the close of holidays as a matter of discipline. When he landed at Winnipeg in a freight car he was arrested by the railway police, charged with breaking and trespassing and was turned over to the Juvenile Court. Judge Hamilton, of the Juvenile Court, is a very warm personal friend of mine and is much interested in our school. He decided to turn him over to me without any other sentence, recommending that I administer what discipline I thought wise in his case. After bringing Stanley home, I wrote the Judge, stating that I had decided to keep him here till the close of holidays. Stanley quite agreed to this and agreed also that the time should be extended beyond the close of holidays if he did not give good conduct from now till then. I have the Judge's letter of approval.

After reviewing the whole situation and noting the type of letters from the parents recommending good conduct it seems to me that it is better to follow out the plan we have outlined.

Trusting that this may meet with your approval,

I am,

Yours respectfully,

JAD/W

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of April 6th, No. 133-0-10, in reference to Gladys Haywahe, No. 0287, and was quite surprised that I had not written you before Christmas in regard to her case. I had talked the matter over very fully with Inspector Hamilton during one of his visits and was under the impression when I sent in the returns that I had also written you.

Last fall, when we had our flu epidemic, Gladys was laid aside for some time unable to attend school. Then for another period we were quarantined with a fear that Scarlet Fever was developing. I talked the matter over with Mr. Reid, the Principal of the Collegiate, and he strongly advised that, owing to the amount of time that Gladys had been out of school, she only write on three of the six subjects required to complete her Grade XI. We followed this advice and she passed successfully on the three subjects, leaving the other three to be written on in June. Gladys is one of our most promising girls, is exceedingly ambitious to be a nurse, has a promise from the Mother Superior of St. Boniface Hospital that she will be admitted on the completion of her Grade XI and we are all exceedingly anxious that she be given the opportunity if it is at all possible. I do not feel however, especially in the light of the cut in grant which has recently taken place that we would be justified in continuing her in the school at our expense for another quarter. I will be very much pleased, therefore, if you can see your way clear to overlook our neglect in writing you in regard to her and allow the per capita grant in her case as from January 1st till the end of the present quarter.

I am,

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 4th instant, the Department allows the Principal of the Brandon Indian Residential School a specified amount to cover the cost of transporting pupils to and from the school. If the transportation expenses exceed the amount allowed by the Department, the school management has to provide the difference.

With the per capita grant reduced, the Brandon School is having a difficult time to operate without a deficit and, consequently, in order to assist them in keeping down expenses, the Department expects Indian agents to cooperate with the Principal by arranging with the parents to either go to the school for the children and return them without cost to the school management, or to arrange with the Indians to provide a part, if not all of the cost of the transportation of their children.

Rev. Sir:

The Department has carefully considered your letter of the 5th instant, but as you have previously been informed, our Appropriation this year has been again reduced and, therefore, we cannot allow more than last year for travelling expenses of pupils to and from the Brandon Indian Residential School this year.

The Department will pay transportation expenses to an amount not exceeding $300. If it is decided later to return any children to Ontario the cost of their transportation will not be included in the amount just mentioned.

You should enlist the cooperation of the Indian agents, with a view to having them arrange for the parents to either come for their children or, in the case of those pupils allowed home on holidays, to provide as much of the cost as possible.

Children should not be sent home unless you feel assured that home conditions are suitable. Pupils residing at a long distance from the school should not be allowed holidays in view of the expenses involved in sending them home.

Yours truly,

Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

From time to time I have received intimations in letters from the Department in regard to children's holidays that the parents should be induced to pay at least part of the cost of transportation. I have been endeavoring as diplomatically as possible to bring these suggestions into effect. Most of the parents are responding very satisfactorily but the parents at Sintaluta have not remitted anything in this connection. Last summer was the first year that I definitely asked them to pay a dollar apiece to cover the cost of operating our van by which we transport them one way. I have written them this year stating that the amount for last year, $1.00 per child, and the same for this year would require to be in my hands before the children left the school. I have received remittance from one family but another letter from another father states that the parents were protesting to the Department at Ottawa against this requirement. I am now writing for your direction as to whether I should send forward the children of parents who refuse to pay this amount or retain them in the school during the holidays. One letter states that they will send a truck and bring the children home on their own account. This, however, does not meet the demand for last year. Your direction and authority in this matter will be greatly appreciated. I would also appreciate an early reply.

Thanking you,

I am,

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle

JAL/W

Walpole Island Ont., June 15th 1936,

Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 3rd instant file 133-0-10 in reference to Francis and Agnes Greenbird daughters of Lazarus Greenbird, I would beg to say that last year Mr. Greenbird had hoped to have the two girls home together as he lives in rather lonely part of the reserve. But as Agnes has a permanent position and is of age, he see no reason why she should not be allowed to do as she see best.

Mr. Greenbird is quite a responsible and reliable Indian, and is living alone and could use Francis at home. Mr. Greenbird also operates an Indian handicraft and souvenir store at Tashoom Park during the summer months, and could use both girls here, but the other 9 or 10 Month Agnes would not like have any position.

Mr. Greenbird is quite willing for Francis to come home, but I do think he would have any objection to Francis staying at the school if it was thought advisable, for another year.

Personally I always feel that the longer the girls can stay at the residential school the better, up to the age of 18 at least. In the present case I think Agnes would be well advised to remain with her position, in Winnipeg, while probably Francis would be better at school, her father home her would be better than the majority of Indian homes.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian affairs,
Ottawa Ont.

Dear Sir,-

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the 8th instant, with reference to Minute of Council of the Sarnia Band regarding Leonard Maness and Hazel Bunce. In your letter, you mention that the Council wishes these two pupils to go home for holidays. We are not prepared to consider allowing the expense that would be involved in carrying out their wishes in this regard.

We have recently received the following reports from the Principal of the Brandon Indian Residential School regarding these two pupils:-

Hazel Bunce - This girl has developed slowly. Last year she was exceedingly anxious to get away but her attitude this year is quite different. She has no home to go to. She has recently learned conditions as far as her mother is concerned and wishes to stay in the West to get work. We would recommend that she be continued on our list for another year but that employment be secured for her and that she be under our supervision as far as possible. Hazel is now eighteen.

Leonard Maness - This boy is sixteen years. He is quite undersize physically; not very reliable and should remain in school.

In view of the Principal's report, the Department considers it in the best interests of these children to remain at the Brandon School for another year. However, you might let me know if the uncle, Wm. E. Jacobs, has a suitable home. If so, we are prepared to consider discharging these children.

Yours truly,

J. C. Trenouth, Esq.,
In charge - Indian Office,

Dear Sir:

Re- Agnes Greenbird No. 0297 and Frances Greenbird No. 0298. Inspector Hamilton brought Agnes to the School yesterday and owing to change in his plans they will not be able to keep a girl in the home for some weeks. Agnes came in this morning to tell me that she had definitely decided not to go East but with her father's consent she is remaining expecting to get employment either with Inspector Hamilton or in some other home. Her services are very satisfactory and she will no doubt be able to get work.

This change of plan on the part of Agnes complicates matters as far as Frances is concerned. Frances is barely sixteen and is under-size and immature for her age, is a bright girl but very much needs protection and guidance; she should remain in school and I do not think the father would wish her to be returned East unless Agnes was with her.

Our graduation exercises have been deferred until Wednesday evening the 24th and I would appreciate it very much if you would send a wire at my expense directing me in regard to Frances. Agnes and also those who know Agnes best are very much of the opinion that she should remain in school for at least another year.

Awaiting your direction,

I am,

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle.
Ottawa, June 24th, 1936.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 20th instant, with reference to the Greenbird girls. The Department wrote you regarding these girls in official letter of the 22nd instant, and you have, no doubt, received our letter by this time.

We have had considerable difficulty in the last two or three years to place the children from Ontario who were sent to the Brandon School several years ago and, therefore, when suitable homes are available, the Department considers it advisable to return these pupils. If such action is delayed it might be much more difficult to find homes next year.

I note that Frances Greenbird has expressed a desire to remain in the West, as she can obtain employment. This attitude does her credit, but in the event of her obtaining a position in which her services proved unsatisfactory, or if she became ill, she would again expect the Brandon School to make provision for her maintenance. Taking these matters into consideration, it is felt that, as the father is now willing to assume responsibility for the two girls, they should be returned to Walpole Island.

Yours truly,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

Dear Sir,

With reference to your letter 133-0-10, dated the 5th instant, in connection with the application for admission to Brandon Residential School of Christina Moar, I have just received a letter from Rev. Dr. Doyle, the Principal, and he stated that there must be some mistake regarding the age of this girl.

I therefore looked up the annuity books and it appears that she was born on Jan. 3rd, 1932. She is therefore 4 years and eight months old.

This family was sent to school as the mother was dead. The children were young and the father could not look after them and at the same time earn his living by trapping. I would therefore ask you to re-consider your decision regarding admitting her; as if she is sent back from school, it will be a very long journey for such a young child to travel alone and I would have difficulty in having her taken care of when she reached the Reserve.

If you decide that this child can be admitted, I will forward the admission form.

Your obedient servant,

Brandon, Man., August 22, 1936.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

I have just received a letter from Indian Agent, Mr. Lovell, of The Pas, stating that Caroline Moar, Maggie Moar and Alice Bonnar have been approved as pupils of this school but that the admission of Christina Moar was not approved.

These children came while I was away on holidays and the application forms have not been forwarded to me and I was very much surprised to note that Christina's age is reported as two and a half years. She seems to us in every way like a child of five, weighs 43 lbs., three pounds more than Alice Bonnar. I understand, also, that the home conditions are such that it made it necessary that these children be cared for.

Will you kindly let me know what should be done under the circumstances. It may be that, after further consideration, you will deem it advisable that her admission should be approved from the date that she came and, if not, should we retain her here at our expense until some definite date when she would become a revenue bearing pupil. The cost of returning her to the reserve is very high. I will be glad to have your instructions as to what should be done under the circumstances.

I am,
Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle,

Dear Sir:

I am writing concerning William Bryant, of the Kamsack Reserve, and recently of File Hills School.

I had to go to Yorkton last Monday with Rosabell Ryder who expects to train in the hospital there. On Sunday Mr. Indian Agent Ostrander, of Kamsack, called me by long distance stating that this boy, now sixteen years of age, was very desirous of taking the technical course for automotive mechanics in connection with the Brandon school and recommended that he do so and as the transportation from Kamsack to Brandon could be made at this time without cost he thought it better that I should bring him over as he felt quite confident the matter would be approved by your Department. William is now in the school and seems to be a very promising boy. No doubt, by this time Mr. Ostrander's letter is before you.

Dear Mr. Sutherland:

On Sunday last we had a visit from the Principal of the Lebret School and an accompanying priest. After supper, and just before leaving, the Principal mentioned that Denis Wasna, of the Sintaluta Reserve, had approached him in regard to having his children transferred from the Brandon School to the Lebret School. The children are, Violet, Hazel, Mary and Catherine Walker, numbered in the same order as, 0407, 0408, 0409, 0437. As I stated to the Principal, it is my opinion that Denis Wasna is not making this request on account of religious conviction and that I did not think that it would be in the interests of this family in particular or of residential school work in general that such requests as his should be granted.

I might say that these girls seem to be getting along usually well in school and that as far as we know they are quite happy and have no desire to change. The third of these four girls has a kleptomaniac tendency which seems to be lessening as time goes on. Mr. Indian Agent Booth can give you further particulars in regard to the family. I felt it only fair that you should have this personal and confidential word.

With kindest regards,

I am, Yours sincerely,

J. A. Doyle.

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 15th instant, No. 133-0-10, in connection with William Bryant, formerly pupil No. 141 of the File Hills Residential School.

In reply I beg to say that this boy was sent to the Brandon School on very short notice, pending some arrangements being made, of a permanent nature, later. The boy's parents are separated and he was living wherever he could find a bed and meal, during the summer holidays, and no one was taking any interest in him. He came to me two days before Doctor Doyle's visit and asked me if he could continue his education at the Brandon School and go to the school when Doctor Doyle came to get another boy, Walter Baldhead, who is continuing his studies at that school. There was no time to make proper arrangements, consequently, when Doctor Doyle came, I explained the circumstances to him, informing him that I had been unable to get in touch with the boy's father, who was away from the reserve at the time, and had not had time to make arrangements through the Department. Doctor Doyle therefore decided that he would take the boy back to the school with him in the car, and await instructions. He also understood that, if the Department did not approve of the admission of the boy to the Brandon School, he would have to be returned to his reserve.

I have since seen the father, Alfred Bryant, of the Cote Band, and he approves of the boy continuing his education and staying away from the reserve, to keep him out of bad company, and I think it would be advisable in this case, as he seems unusually ambitious and there is certainly nothing for him on the reserve and no home fit for a young person to live in. As you know, I am not very much in favour of forcing higher education upon a young Indian against his will, but this boy begged to be given a chance, and I believe his intentions are good.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Your obedient servant,

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Indian Agent.

On October 8th I wrote you concerning the truancy of Cecil Peters, #352, and Thomas Linklater, #266. No word has come to us in regard to Cecil Peters but this morning a couple of letters received by boys here from Thomas reveal that he had reached Ontario, worked for a couple of weeks on a farm and when writing the letter, October 11th, was employed at Westboro, Ontario, six miles from Ottawa with a man who had a store and a small farm. He said he milked one Jersey cow, fed a few pigs, etc. He stated that he was not returning to his home at Wabowden for some time.

Since these boys have gone, others have run away. When Cecil and Tommy were not brought back they seemed to feel that the matter was not taken very seriously. In conversation with some of the senior boys I find also that they have a notion that if they get to Ontario they will not be brought back. We have had wonderful Indian Summer weather and have been observing quarantine regulations on account of the prevalence of infantile paralysis in the district. We feel that it is exceedingly urgent and essential for the discipline of our school and also for the good of the boy himself that Thomas be returned. The Mounted Police here have had the matter in hand and in conversation with them this morning it was decided that I should write you at once for authority to have this boy brought back.

Awaiting your reply,

I am,

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle.

With reference to the above and in compliance with the instructions of the C.O. Saskatoon Sub/Division dated the 15th Inst., I have to report as follows:

1. This early am., a phone message was received at this detachment from Sergt. R.W.H. Williams Saskatoon Sub/Div., he advised me that a telegram had been received this early am. from Insp. J.E. Keppelton, C.O.C. Brandon Sub/Div., this to the effect that the above named and Harry Royal, two Indian Boys, were believed to be at Royal's house, Dundurn Dist., further that if this were correct the Boys were to be held for escort back to The Indian Residential School, Brandon, Man.

2. I departed Hanley per police car code 1896 this same early am., patrolling to Dundurn, thence to the Moose Wood Indian Reserve. John Squill, father of Harry Royal and Archie Eagle, the owner of the Reserve, were interviewed. They informed me that the Boys were on the Reserve, that they wished them to return, further that the Boys only complaint about the School at Brandon was that they did not get enough food and it wasn't properly cooked, thus they ran away.

3. The two Boys were taken into custody and patrol con- v'd to Saskatoon where they were handed over to the Provost at the Saskatoon Detachment and Sergt. R.W.H. Williams informed that the boys were in custody.

4. I returned to Hanley per police car this early pm. A receipt for the above named and R. Royal, issued at Hanley detachment by Const. T. Playford, Provost, is held on file at this point.

Re: Alex POLL (Indian) Juvenile Delinquent. Theft of Mail - Oxbow district, Saskatchewan.

Relative to the above, W.A. Staples, farmer, Oxbow district, got in L.D. telephonic communication with the writer at 10 a.m., this date, he stating:

"My neighbour, Wilfred ROWLEY, brought out my mail from Oxbow last night, leaving it at the north-west corner of my farm, but when I went for it this morning, I could not find it, and I am sure that it has been stolen and would like to have the matter investigated."

I left at 10.30 a.m., per auto hired livery and patrolled to Glen Ewen, where I was informed that an Indian lad had walked into the Village that morning from the west, about half-an-hour before my arrival.

I located this lad in the hotel, where he was eating a meal, and he gave his name as "Billy POLL" and that he had walked from the Indian Reserve at Broadview, where he had been staying with his uncle Andrew ALEXSON, since 1935, and he had left the Reserve in the a.m., of the 6th instant, and he was not in possession of any identification. In his possession he had a catalogue and a copy of the "Producer" newspaper, addressed to W.A. Staples, Oxbow. On questioning him, he admitted that he had taken a bundle of mail, which he had found on the top of a corner fence post, N.W., of Glen Ewen, and he had left the balance of the mail in a granary where he had spent the night.

This lad took me to the granary where he had slept the night previous, and I found three copies of the Free Press, a Pictorial Review and the Oxbow Herald, all addressed to W.A. Staples. He stated that there were four letters in the bundle of mail, which he claimed he had taken at the foot of the fence post where he had taken the mail. I continued my patrol to the corner where this mail had been left by Wilfred ROWLEY, where I was met by W.A. STAPLES and Wilfred ROWLEY, but no letters could be found so I questioned this lad further and he finally admitted that he had opened the letters this a.m., and threw them away between highway No.18 and the railroad track, where I patrolled to and found the four letters, they just being circular letters, and Wilfred ROWLEY stated that he was sure that there were no letters of importance in the bundle of mail he had brought out from Oxbow for Mr. Staples.

I am satisfied that all the mail was recovered, which I handed over to W.A. Staples, and he stated that he would not prefer any charges in the matter, being as the culprit was an Indian and just a lad.

I escorted this lad to Glen Ewen and got in L.D. telephonic communication with our Broadview Detachment, but failed to receive any information in regards to this lad and he was not known to Mr. McKenzie, the Indian Agent, in Charge of the Reserve at Broadview.

Acting on your telephonic instructions, I detained the above named and escorted him to Carnduff and he stated as follows:

"I was born on Aug. 7th, 1920 at or near Dunseth, N.D. My father is dead, he died about four years ago on the Turtle-Mountain Reserve, near Dunseth. I belong to the Indian Reserve in the Turtle Mountains, North Dakota. My Mother got married again about two years ago to an Indian by the name of Louis DESCHANT or DESCHAMP. My step-father took me to the Indian Reserve near Broadview in September 1935, and left me with my Uncle, Andrew ALEXSON, who is parted from his wife, but living with another Indian woman. Mr. McKenzie is the Agent on the reserve, but I never saw him. I helped my uncle to do some work on the farm and I got along good with him and he was kind to me. I wanted to see my Mother, who is now living on the Turtle Mountain Reserve, so I left the Broadview reserve on Saturday morning last, to walk to Dunseth. My Uncle gave me some food to eat on the way, but I finished it last night. I slept in granaries coming down. I got to Manor yesterday afternoon and kept on coming south. When I was some distance from Manor, I came across some mail on top of a fence post, which I took, so as to have something to read, and took it to a granary about one mile south, where I stayed for the night. It was mostly newspapers. The letters I opened and threw them away as I am an U.S. Indian and I never lived in Canada before my step-father brought me here. I have no identification card and the Indian Agent at Broadview did not know that I was leaving, but my Uncle said that he would notify Mr. McKenzie that I had left. When we entered Canada, we came through Northgate, we were travelling in a car, just my step-father reported when we entered Canada. He and my Mother stayed only three days in Canada and they then returned to the States. I have never heard from my Mother or Step-father since they left me in Canada, and I have never written to them. I can read and write, I went to school in the States reaching the sixth grade. I have never been in trouble before. I have three sisters and two brothers younger than myself."

I got in telephonic communication with the Canadian Immigration at Northgate, Sask., but they had no record of the DESCHANT or DESCHAMP family entering Canada in 1935 and neither did the American Immigration Office at Northgate, N.D.

I also got in telephonic communication with Mr. McKenzie, Indian Agent at Broadview, Sask., but he had no knowledge of this boy being on the reserve at Broadview, and he was positive that he could not possibly have been there since 1935, but there was an Indian by the name of Andrew ALEXSON, who was living with another woman, being separated from his wife, whom he would interview in regards to the above named.

I still continued to question this lad and on the 11th, inst., he finally admitted that his name was Alex POLL and that he had run away from the White Bear reserve, near Carlyle, and he had been adopted, and he wanted to go and see his Mother at Dunseth.

I got in telephonic communication with Mr. Morrison, Farm Instructor on the White Bear Reserve, and he stated that he was looking for Alex POLL, an Indian lad 14 years of age, who had run away from the reserve during the night of the 7th, and 8th, inst., and I informed Mr. Morrison that I had this lad in my custody.

I had a telephone message from Mr. Morrison on the 12th, inst., who requested that I escort this lad to the Indian School at Brandon, Manitoba, he having received these instructions from Mr. McKenzie at Broadview and I informed Mr. Morrison that any instructions in regards to me escorting this lad would have to come through my Officer Commanding at Weyburn, and Mr. Morrison stated that he would take it up further with Mr. McKenzie.

Continued on Sheet 3
Acting on your telephonic instructions in the a.m., of the 13th instant, and my telephone message in the a.m. of the 14th instant, I escorted the above named to the Indian School, Brandon, Manitoba, where I handed him over to the Matron in charge, together with some clothes which had been donated to him by some citizens of Carnduff, via private auto, on the 14th instant, but I am only charging mileage in lieu of railroad fare, which amounts to $6.50, being as I will be engaged on other police duties this week, there being no train service from this point to Brandon on a Sunday, and to use train service, it would take two full days.

I might state, that when I picked up the above named, the clothes he was wearing were very ragged and dirty and he himself was filthy, so I gave him a bath and was successful in obtaining for him a change of clothes from a few of the citizens of Carnduff, and I burnt his old clothes. I did not keep him in the cell, but he slept on a cot in a spare room at these Detachment quarters.

Manitoba. 16.8.39.

Russell MALLET (Indian) Missing from Indian Residential School Brandon, Man.

(1) Further reference to the above matter. The Indian School has been kept in touch with regarding any information they might have received in this respect, but they have had no word regarding the whereabouts of this boy.

(2) As it is quite evident he has left this district, there is nothing more that can be done at this detachment in the line of inquiries as when this boy left this area, he was lost touch of until he showed up around Regent and Deloraine districts when a report was submitted from Deloraine detachment. This was the last that was heard or seen of MALLET. At that time it was thought that he had gone into the U.S.

(3) No report has been received by Dr. DOYLE of the Indian School at Brandon regarding this boy from any source although he has made many inquiries through the children of the school, and other Indians coming from different parts of the Province whom he has been in contact with. Also from different Indian Agents whom he has corresponded with, there has been no report. It would therefore appear that MALLET has not gone to his home and has succeeded in keeping away from other Indians in the Province that come to Brandon and district. This might lead to believing that the boy did make his way into the United States.

(4) Under the circumstances there does not appear to be much that can be done at this point and should MALLET be located and Dr. DOYLE informed other than through this Force he will notify this detachment. Might I therefore ask that this file be closed, and should any further assistance be required in this matter, a further report be submitted from here.

Brandon, Man., Sept. 11, 1939

The Secretary,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

Last May in writing you concerning what pupils should graduate and which should continue in school, I stated that Walter Bear, No. 461, now eighteen years of age, was taking grade XII, and if he succeeded in passing with the required percentage he wanted to go on to Normal School. If he failed to secure this standing it was tentatively understood that he would not continue in school here. He failed in four and a half subjects, and notwithstanding the definite arrangements we made with him he came back with the other pupils and asked that his case be reconsidered. He saved $12.00 out of what he earned this summer and has handed that over to me and has now secured a short period of work on a farm and states that he can make up $25.00, including this $12.00, toward his fees for this coming year. I talked to the Principal of the Collegiate concerning him. He considers Walter a bright and promising student, thinks he did not apply himself as diligently as he might have done. I told Walter I would write you and await your decision as to whether he should be continued in school or dropped entirely from our list.

I might say that we are filled to the limit of our pupilage but will be willing to carry Walter as another extra pupil if the Department thinks he should go on.

He is a bright likeable chap, fairly ambitious, and I think if given this opportunity will de-
The Secretary, Dept. of Mines & Resources.

vote himself more faithfully to his studies than he has in the past.

Awaiting your direction, I am

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle

Sir:-

PRINCIPAL

Brandon, Man., Sept. 5, 1939

Dr. Thos. Robertson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Regina, Saskatchewan.

Dear Dr. Robertson:

Last Thursday I had conversation with you from Carlyle over telephone concerning the children of Nelson Sammy. Since then I have been exceedingly busy getting pupils back from holidays, and I have been unable to write you until today.

Three of the Sammy children have been with us for the past two years as pupils. When I went to Carlyle the other day Mr. Morrison laid the case before me of the two younger children, hoping that we could take them. I of course objected on account of their age, Thelma is four years old and Kenneth three, and on this account I phoned you.

Chester Ewalk and his wife had taken all five children after the death of the mother and grandparents. He felt however that he could not continue to care for them, and no other home on the Reserve seemed either able or willing to undertake it, so we brought them with us. We have our full quota of pupils without these children, and unless the Department would care to regard them as supernumerary, we would be keeping them without cost to the Department until some other pupils would be discharged.

Awaiting the direction of the Department in the matter, I am

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle

JAD/RS. PRINCIPAL.

P.S. In the meantime we will have application forms made out and sent forward to the Agent in the regular way.

Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of the following letter from Dr. J.A. Doyle, Principal of the Brandon Indian residential school:

"I have a letter from the Rev. Principal of the Indian residential school at Lebret, requesting that Florence Sammy, No. 0480, Priscilla Sammy, No. 0481, and Richard Sammy, No. 490, be transferred to the Lebret school on account of a request made by the father who is now on trial for murder. His request also included that the two younger children who are with us be returned to his parents. I have written the Rev. Father stating that we will be glad to comply with the Department's wish in this matter and would be pleased if an early decision in the matter was reached as we have now more pupils enrolled than we should have."

The application forms for Florence and Priscilla Sammy were forwarded to the Department in August, 1937, and were approved by Mr. E.A.W.R. McKenzie, Indian Agent. The form stated that the children were Protestants.

From the contents of Dr. Doyle's letter it might be inferred that the children should have been recognized as Roman Catholics.

I should appreciate it if you would make immediate inquiries with a view to definitely ascertaining whether the Sammy children should be educated under Protestant or Roman Catholic auspices. If the father has always been recognized as a Protestant the Department does not see any reason why the children should be placed in the Qu'Appelle school.

Yours truly,

Dr. Thos. Robertson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Regina, Sask.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir:

Re: Your #133-0-10 of September 29th,
Letter from Dr. J. A. Doyle, Brandon School,
re Sammy Children.

Immediately upon receipt of the above letter I wrote our Agent at Broadview, also J. R. Morrison, our Farming Instructor at White Bear, for information.

I am today in receipt of a letter from W.J.B. Hall, Clerk-in-Charge at Broadview, in which he states, "I understand that these children were originally at the request of the father admitted to Protestant school and that he was recognized as a Protestant." He goes on to say, "I may say that the early part of this week one of the Priests of the Qu'Appelle School was at this office and mentioned the matter to me and said that Nelson Sammy had asked him to take these children but as long as they were well provided for he was not concerned any further and now that they were at Brandon it would be quite satisfactory to them."

Mr. J. R. Morrison, Farming Instructor, replied as follows:
"Re Nelson Sammy family now in Brandon School. Children namely Florence, Priscilla and Richard were admitted to Brandon School at their Father's own request. The two younger needed care and as Nelson Sammy's parents are destitute and morally unfit to care for them they went along with their sisters and brother to Brandon. I do not think the Father and Mother had any religious ties although both of them attended Protestant Schools, namely File Hills and Brandon."

I have not made a special trip to White Bear to go into this matter but will do so if you consider the information contained herein is not definite enough.

Yours truly,

Thos. Robertson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

Cases such as this occur at frequent intervals and I believe it would be advisable for you to discuss the matter with the Principals of the residential schools in Manitoba with a view to arranging with them that when such cases arise certain children at present in the school and whose parents are able to support them and live on the Reserves where day schools are located should be discharged to make room for these needy cases. I may add that in the past the Department has been favourably disposed to allowing certain pupils, especially girls, to remain in residential schools after they reach the age of 16 if good reasons for such action are given by the Principal and approved by the Indian Agent. However, in view of the fact that the number of children of school age is apparently increasing and the further consideration that due to the conditions now confronting us there is no immediate prospect of our securing funds to provide increased pupilage at Indian residential schools, it is considered that in future it will be necessary to adhere more strictly to the provision of the Indian Act requiring discharge of pupils at 16 years of age.

I feel you will agree with me that it is not fair to deprive children of education simply because the accommodation that might be available for them in a residential school is being used by those who have had the advantage of residential school training for some years and who have reached the age of 16 years.

Dear Sir:

Following your letter of February 26, I have gone over very carefully every pupil in the school who is sixteen years of age and over. In a letter which I have just written, we have listed 31 pupils who might be discharged. Before listing in detail those whom we recommend to be continued in school, I would like to make some report on the work we have been trying to do during the past year along the lines referred to in my letter of May 29, 1939.

Class in Home Nursing. The class in home nursing is progressing favourably. There are twelve girls being trained and will be ready for examination at the end of this month. Some of these girls are quite intent to train as Nurses if at all possible. Miss Rosabelle Ryder will graduate from St. Boniface Hospital next Monday. Though she did not possess outstanding ability as a student, she had a set purpose and a dogged determination and has maintained a very excellent standard, especially in her practical work, in her entire course. There is no question in my mind but that a number of these girls could do equally as well.

During this school year, we have had employed an extra teacher in the sewing department, with the view of giving the older girls a thorough training in all kinds of needlework. Twenty-four girls have been trained in this class this year, every girl has made two complete sets of clothing for herself, one or more other articles made-over, such as child's coat out of an old coat, boy's pants out of an old pair of pants, two or more articles of clothing for a smaller child, three articles of clothing for a baby, sewn by hand; two or more house dresses; one or more boys' night-shirts, one or more pairs of pyjamas, one or more nightgowns,
one jumper-dress for a little girl.

Careful account has been kept as to efficiency, quality of work, speed, etc., and they rank as follows: Excellent, 13; good, 5; fair, 5; poor, 1.

Each girl retains the patterns used in all of these garments.

This department has taken in old coats from families in town and made them over for younger children and their work has been decidedly acceptable. We are quite pleased with the start we have made in this department and are confident we have given a number of the girls the feeling that they can go ahead and do this kind of work when they go home.

During the winter months we have conducted two classes in Agriculture and Stockraising. Mr. Zealand has taken the Diploma Course in the Agricultural College, Mr. Waldon has had some training in the Agricultural College, and we have secured from the Department a splendid supply of pamphlets and booklets covering the whole field. Examinations were held at the close of the course in which fifteen boys took part, securing an average of 76.2%, ten over 60%, the highest 92.5%. We would like very much to give some kind of a certificate to those taking over 60%. If the Department can provide something of this kind we would be very pleased indeed to have them do so, and present these certificates at our closing exercises.

As we did not have a suitable Beehouse, we decided to destroy our bees last fall and purchase new colonies this spring. Instead of purchasing eight, as we had last year, we have secured twelve. The boys are taking a good interest in this Department and instruction in Beekeeping was given in the course during the winter.

From time to time we have been having a few pupils tested by the Mental Clinic which carries on very helpful work, from the Mental Hospital here. For our own information and to correct our impressions if they were wrong, that the majority of our pupils are an average of two years or more behind the ordinary white child, we had eleven pupils of sixteen years of age tested this year. These form a cross-section of our student body and were not picked either with a view of cleverness or dullness. The following list and standing is the result.

The average of the above shows for the eleven pupils a mental age of 11.5/12, and I.Q. of 75 on the basis of a chronological age of 15. Omitting Jean Prince who is above the average for a normal white pupil, the average is 10.9/12 years, I.Q. 72. In my mind, the inference from the above is that 16 as a general thing is too young for Indian pupils to leave school. With a mental age of 10 or 11 it is impossible for them to get as much out of these practical courses which we are trying to give them, as they would a year or two later in life.

With this in mind, and also keeping in mind the urgency of getting the older pupils out of the way as early as possible to make way for younger ones who might be available, I have gone over very carefully and discussed with members of the Staff each pupil 16 years and over, and beg to recommend that the following remain in the school for at least the coming school year:

Dear Sir:

In my letter today in regard to pupils who should, or in our opinion should not, graduate, the first name in the graduating list is that of Alma Cree, No. 0288. I appreciate exceedingly that you left this girl with us for this year. I think in addition to giving her extra training in household art, to which she has responded splendidly, she has developed in character and dependability.

Alma is an exceedingly kindly, likeable, and responsive girl. She is quite small and slight, has a very gentle manner, but does her work with thoroughness and seems to enjoy real good health. This girl comes from Oka, Quebec, and according to Miss Daly, our Intermediate teacher, who taught at Caughnawaga for two years, Alma has not a suitable home to which she can go. She has a sister, I believe, at Sioux St. Marie who is married, but she states that she does not want to go to either her home or to her sister's. Last summer she visited with the Anderson family on the File Hills Reserve, Doris Anderson, a pupil here, being an intimate friend of hers. She met a young man, while there, Anderson by name and a cousin of her friend, whom I believe is employed at Punnichy Agency. They have been corresponding during the year and there would be some indication that he has matrimonial intentions. The Andersons have invited her again this year and I wrote the Agent, Mr. Dodds as to the advisability of letting her go, with a view of making her home there quite indefinitely. His reply is unfavourable to this propos-

Re: Alma Cree - No. 0288

Dear Doctor Doyle:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of May 9, in which you discuss the case of the above noted pupil.

I am personally of the opinion that an attempt should be made by you, either to keep this particular pupil in your home for domestic duties there, or to find for her a home in which she would receive additional training in household duties, under the direction of a capable housewife. It might be well, also, to have an arrangement with the party or parties concerned that they would report to you on her progress from time to time.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

Since writing the enclosed letter, I have your letter of May 9, No. 133-0-10; and in reply wish to write concerning John Charles Spence.

This boy returned to the school within twenty-four hours after leaving. I consider him in many ways a very promising boy. He is somewhat easily led and was induced to go with the others, and rode the freight train as far as Broadview but fully decided to return. He came straight to the Office, confessed everything, asked to be reinstated in the life of the school, stating that he was willing to take any punishment that we might give him, and wants to stay here for another year; at the end of that time he states that he does not intend to return to the Reserve, which is Nelson House, but wants to work out and make good at farming in a white community. I feel quite confident that this boy is so sincere in his intentions, that he will make good, and that this next year in school will do him a great deal of benefit. I would appreciate very much if you will give this request of mine favourable consideration. I am

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle
PRINCIPAL.

Dear Sir:

Your letter of the 8th instant, No. 133-0-10, concerning Donald Bigknife reached me Saturday evening. Two days before I received word from the R.C.M.P. Office saying that Donald was at Wolseley, Saskatchewan, and that they were sending a man down to pick him up; but the man did not return until yesterday afternoon. It seems that Donald was apprehended and in care of the detachment at Wolseley, but before the Officer from here arrived he had slipped away from them. On receiving your letter I immediately had them cancel any further effort in regard to securing this boy.

A few days ago I received word from Mr. Hillhouse, Farm Instructor on the Reserve at Sintaluta, stating that Edwin Ryder had been located over the Montana border, in the Sweetgrass country. I called the Mounted Police Office and asked them to take no further action in regard to him; then yesterday I received word from them stating that he also was detained at Wolseley. I expect he was caught entering the United States without passport or identification card and sent back; but in view of the contents of your letter I felt that I should not have Edwin return to the school, even from Wolseley. I have also advised them that no further action should be taken in regard to Joe Mason. Trusting that these matters meet with your approval, I am

Yours respectfully,

JAD/RS.
PRINCIPAL.

Dear Sir:

After receiving your letter of May 8, No. 133-0-10, concerning Donald Bigknife, I phoned the R.C.M.P. office here giving them the contents of your letter, also wrote Indian Agent Dodds of Balcarres and Principal Rhodes of the File Hills School. The R.C.M.P. Officer here informed me that Donald had already been apprehended, was brought to Wolseley for transfer to Brandon, but that he had slipped away from them and at that time they were out looking for him. On Wednesday the Inspector of the Force stationed at Brandon called me up stating that Donald had been secured in the vicinity of Balcarres and the Officer evidently had been in touch with Mr. Dodds and I think also Mr. Rhodes, and stated that there was a very strong feeling that this boy should not be allowed to get away with this escapade without being brought back and punished. They felt it was very bad for the boy and also bad for the schools concerned. Donald had been a chronic deserter at File Hills, he claims that he ran away twenty-seven times, and he was brought here on that account. I found myself absolutely in harmony with their judgment in this matter and felt that under the circumstances the only right thing to do was to have him brought back. He arrived early yesterday morning and I am sure that his return is having and will have a wholesome affect on our school. I am also quite satisfied that he will remain without giving us any trouble until the end of June, at which time we will discharge him in the regular way. Trusting that this action meets with your approval, I am

Yours respectfully,

Dear Sir:

We also received a few days later the Director's letter announcing that there would be a reduction in payments made in our grant to 92.24% of our allotted pupilage. We will certainly find it difficult to finance on this reduction, but will face up to it and do the best we possibly can. We realize, I think, very keenly the strenuous and difficult times through which we are passing and will have to pass before our difficulties are cleared away.

Our chief concern now will be to secure pupils up to the 92.24% of our allotment.

In the supplementary list of 17 which you submit, there are two about which we are deeply concerned: No. 0494, Irene Gaddie, is one of the most promising girls we have in the school. Dear Sir,

I respectfully beg to request authority to keep home my two sons, William and Reginald Murdoch who are now with me during the holidays from the Brandon Indian Boarding School.

My reasons for making this request is that the boys state they have not sufficient nourishing food and are therefore driven to stealing in order to satisfy their hunger.

Also, I do not consider that the boys can obtain a due and proper education when they have to work half days at ordinary farm work.

I was a pupil at the Boarding School and had thought there would have been improvement in the administration of the Industrial Schools by the time my boys would be there, but I am convinced that the present system of Indian education is an injustice to Indian children.

To keep children at an Industrial School with modern methods for farming and domestic science and then turn them back to an Indian Reserve with no equipment, at the most susceptible age, is certainly not for the benefit of the Indians.

Please send me permission to keep my boys at home from now on.

Thanking you in anticipation,

Yours truly,

S.J. Murdoch,
Fisher River Indian Reserve.

Brandon, Man., September 26, 1940

The Secretary,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.,

Dear Sir:

A couple of weeks ago Inspector Hamilton called my attention to the fact that there was a group of children at Scantebury who should be sent away to school and he recommended, as I was waiting in Winnipeg for the arrival of the boat from Norway House that I call on Howard Sinclair, this I did and he decided to send four of his children. Both the agent and the Missionary, Mr. Sage gave decided approval to this so we brought these children a week ago Monday. Also Madeline Grisdale, a child whose parents are dead and who is very seriously neglected. Then Harry Starr the next week sent his two girls, Dorcas and Munice.

I am enclosing Application Forms with Health Certificates for the two Starr girls and Madeline, but Harold Sinclair was away when we called at his place to have the Application signed and we expected to contact him at Middlechurch where he had gone to pick potatoes, and I have returned the forms for his four children to Mr. Sage who will secure signatures as early as possible and forward a copy of the form for each child to you.

I am

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle,
Principal.

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.
PRINCIPAL

Brandon, Man., September 26, 1940

The Secretary,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of September 2, st., No. 133-0-10 concerning the $150.00 grant toward travelling expenses, and will review the situation.

About thirteen years ago this School was very short of pupils and the Department arranged to have over forty sent from Ontario and Quebec. When I took over the School eleven years ago most of these eastern pupils were still here. A number were discharged that year, prior to the School being emptied for a new building. The Department at that time was paying all holiday and other transportation expenses. When agreement was entered into with the Department that a definite sum would be allowed to this School toward transportation expenses, the expenses of graduates going east were paid over and above this allotted amount. Not only was there definite agreement between the School and the Department to this fact but during the eleven years this practice has been followed and all expenses of pupils going to eastern Canada were paid over and above this allotted amount. Therefore when the Department's letter arrived stating that the allotment of $350.00 would be reduced to $150.00 I naturally took it that the old arrangement would hold good. I feel therefore that we should receive the full $150.00 apart from the amount paid for the transportation of Fraleigh Shanks who was sent east.

I am Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle
Principal.
Ottawa,
October 5, 1940.

Reverend Sir:

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith Application for Admission with Health Certificate for Amos Williams of the Griswold Reserve.

Amos Williams, the father, has given a good deal of trouble to the agent on this reserve. On November 5th, 1938 this young lad was placed in this school with some pressure from the agent, but with the father's approval. The father came to the school quite frequently, and created as much discontent with the boy as he seemed able to do.

Then during the following holiday, he took the boy into the United States stating that he was not returning. We therefore on August 29th, 1939 applied for his discharge. For some time past Williams has been on the reserve with his boy but refused to send him to any school. Mr. Young has taken the matter up and has insisted that he be sent to school. He arrived today.

This situation accounts for the Application not being signed by the father. He however did sign the application two years ago.

I am,

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle

0494. Irene Gaddie. I consider this girl one of the most promising we have had in this School. She also is in grade II, is giving good attention to her work, and no doubt will clear the year. She also wishes to be a nurse, and we have no hesitation in requesting that she be continued.

0509. Connie Gaddie. This girl is a sister of Irene above, is a good student, has a pleasing manner, meets people with composure as does her sister, is ambitious to be a teacher. We have tried her out in the Junior room, and her work has been very satisfactory. She gives real promise and is anxious to continue at School. We recommend it most heartily.

0518. Jean Prince. This girl is a strong, healthy girl, has a good intellect, was given an "I.Q." test by the Clinic at the Mental Hospital last year and her mental age was higher than her chronological age. Her people are anxious for her to continue in School, and she expresses a desire to go on and train for a nurse; and while we recommend it her ambition is not as all absorbing as with perhaps any of the others in this list.

0521. Grace Johnnie. This girl is just 16 years of age and had her early training at Portage La Prairie, was selected as perhaps the most promising girl they had. She has been the most adaptable in connection with the hospital ward and nursing generally of any girl we have had in the School, is ambitious to be a nurse, and our staff would be unanimous in the wish that she would be given the privilege of continuing in School in order to achieve this end.

395. Victor Williams. This boy has no appearance of being more than 13 years of age. Intellectually I am sure he would not rate above 10 if that old. His Mother however contends that he is 16 and we have left his age at that. His Mother who belongs to Selkirk spends practically all her time in Winnipeg, is by no means reputable, and we are quite convinced this boy should remain in School.

Dear Sir:

I am writing this special letter in connection with the report which is forwarded herewith, in regard to the pupils who are now 16 years of age or over, and whom we believe should remain in school for another year. They are as follows:

0364 Emily Linklater. This is the girl whom you have been caring for medically ever since she came to this school. Her trouble was congenital hip dislocation. She is still under the care of Doctor Gibson. We have taken her in twice recently and she is due to go again at the end of this week. Emily is doing well in needle work and with another year's training at which time we hope she will be in a better physical condition, she should be able to earn her own living if suitable employment could be obtained for her. There is no doubt nothing else to do but to leave her in this school for another year.

0384 Muriel Cline. This girl's parents are separated. She has no place to go, has just turned 15, is very much under normal both in mentality and personality and should remain in this school for another year.

0493 Selma Francis. This girl is now 17 years of age. She is a good student, ambitious to be a nurse, is doing well in Collegiate taking grade II. She and also her people are anxious that she should remain in school for another year to secure grade I2. Her father is serving overseas with the Canadian Forces, served also in the last war, and we most heartily recommend that she be allowed to continue her studies.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 3rd instant the Department is prepared to approve the transfer of Henry Bear from the Round Lake Residential School to the Brandon Residential School. I note that this boy is past Grade 8 and presumably the mother wishes him to attend high school. It should be distinctly understood that in transferring him to Brandon the Department will only pay his per capita grant at that school. Any extra expenses that may be incurred in sending him to high school will have to be paid by the mother. These extra expenses will probably amount to $100.00 or more each academic year. I am so advising the Principal of the Brandon Residential School.

Reverend Sir:

The Department has received an application for the transfer of Henry Bear from the Round Lake Residential School to the Brandon Residential School. This boy is 14 years of age and is past Grade 8 and I understand his mother wishes him to attend high school.

I am advising Indian Agent Kerley that the Department will approve the transfer of the boy on the understanding that we will only be responsible for the per capita grant. Any expenses that may be incurred over and above the per capita grant in order to enable him to attend high school will have to be paid by his mother. Her payment should include, of course, the tuition fees and other expenses and I am advising Mr. Kerley that the total amount will be $100.00 or more for each academic year. I further understand that his mother is able to handle this extra expense due to the fact that the boy's father is in the Army and she is no doubt receiving separation allowance and assigned pay.

Yours truly,

Stephen BIGSTONE - Runaway Boy.
Indian Residential School, Brandon, Manitoba.

Brandon Detachment case.

1. With reference to the above I have to report that Mr. R.T. CHAPLIN, Principal of the Indian Residential School, Brandon, Man., called at this detachment in the P.M. of 19-12-41 and reported that Stephen BIGSTONE, one of the students at the Indian School had run away. He requested that inquiries be made by this force with a view to locating this boy and advising Mr. CHAPLIN of his whereabouts.

2. Stephen BIGSTONE is described as being 15 years of age, 5ft. 5ins., about 120 lbs., black hair, dark eyes, dark complexion, and having Indian features. He was dressed in overalls and a smock, colour not known. He ran away from the school about 3 weeks ago.

3. Mr. CHAPLIN stated that this boy's home is on a reserve near Carlyle, Sask., but that inquiries at that point by Mr. CHAPLIN have failed to show any trace of him, and he is not believed to be there. He also has relatives on the Indian Reserve near Maple Creek, and it is possible that he has gone to that point. It is believed that this relative's name is Gordon CAMERON.

4. This boy ran away in the latter part of September of this year and was apprehended on the reserve near Maple Creek.

5. Mr. CHAPLIN does not wish to have him apprehended this time, if he is located, but wishes to be advised of his whereabouts.

6. May inquiries be made please by the Maple Creek, Sask. detachment with a view to ascertaining whether Stephen BIGSTONE is at that point. Extra copies attached for the information of "W" Division.

Sir,

I beg to advise you that at the beginning of last December I received an application for the admission to Brandon Residential School of Robert Chubb, aged 13, son of Flora Chubb No; 18 God's Lake Band. There was no covering letter with the application.

I wrote to Rev: H.E.Young, the United Church Missionary at God's Lake Reserve, asking him for some further information regarding this boy, and for reasons why the application was for admission to 'Brandon' Residential School, instead of Norway House Residential School, and I enclose herewith for your information, a copy of Rev: Mr Young's reply.

The boy's mother is a widow. The boy himself has according to the application, attended the God's Lake U.C. Seasonal School for five summers, and he is now 13 years of age. According to the teacher's report for the 1941 season of this day school, the boy is in grade 5, and out of 60 days the school was open, he attended for 17 days, being absent 43 days.

Will you please advise me if the Department will approve of this boy's admission to Brandon School, and assume the expense of his transportation from Norway House to Winnipeg by boat, and from Winnipeg to Brandon by train this coming summer. If so, I will forward the application. I may say that the Physical Examination of this boy turned out good excepting that at the time he was examined, on October 2nd last, he had a cold. He was examined By Dr Moir of God's Lake.

Your obedient Servant

The Secretary

Dear Mr Lazenby

Re.: Robert Chubb, File 22-B

In reply to yours of Dec. 8th, I have this to report. Flora Chubb states that she wants her boy to go to Brandon School instead of Norway House because she wants him to learn to speak English properly, and to learn to do something. She says that the boys that have come back from Norway House do not appear to know very much. She would like her boy to be able to speak English well enough to interpret for the Missionary in Church. She also states that it was the wish of the boy's father, John Chubb #18, before he died, that Robert should go to Brandon.

She was hoping the boy would be able to go out last fall before freeze-up. I imagine she would be glad to have him go as soon as possible. Perhaps he could go to Norway House with the freighters next spring and go out by boat if this is passed by the Government.

The boy has shown some marked ability in the musical line, and, I believe the teacher last year reported that he seemed to be bright in school. The only school he has attended has been the school held here in the summer time.

I sincerely hope that something can be done soon to encourage them. The boy seems to be anxious to go, and the mother is anxious that he amount to something.

I was going to suggest to them that he go to Norway House first, and if he showed promise there he could be sent to Brandon later. However, I decided to await your opinion on the matter. The above are all the reasons she has given me for wanting him to go to Brandon, and she is aware of the fact that it will be a long time before he would be able to come home again.

Hoping to hear from you again soon regarding this application, I am,

Yours very truly,

Signed:- H.Egerton Young

Dear Sir:

I hereby make special application for the following children who are 16 years of age or over, to remain in School for the coming year.

0509 Connie Gaddie - 17 years of age. Connie is now attending the Brandon Collegiate taking her grade 11. She has proved herself a steady, studious girl, anxious to go on with her course. She is aiming at Normal training so that she may take a teaching position. With her steady record of the past years, I have no doubt that she will make good if she has the opportunity; and strongly recommend that she be allowed to come back next year to take her grade 12 at the Brandon Collegiate.

0553 Edith Starr - 16 years of age. Edith is taking her grade 9 with us. She is one of our outstanding pupils. She has a bright, quick, willing disposition. She is studious in the classroom and energetic in her work. She is anxious to go on with her studies, and I would recommend that she be allowed to come back next year and take her grade 10 with us.

0458 Myrtle Spence - 16 years of age. Myrtle is a girl small of stature, but quick and bright disposition. She is taking her grade 7 this year. A little while ago her mother who is working in Winnipeg, was here on a visit, and asked me if it would be possible for Myrtle to continue in School for another year and get her grade 8. As the mother is working out there is no home for Myrtle to go to, and it would be decidedly to her advantage to remain here another year until she is a little fuller developed both mentally and physically.
Page 2.

0384 Muriel Cline - 17 years of age. The father of this girl is in Norway House; and the mother in Selkirk, with none too good a name. The mother wanted Muriel home this year so that she might marry her to a man in Selkirk, and thus have a home for her own self. Muriel is mentally backward and somewhat childish. She is in grade 6. This past year she has developed considerably. I wrote the Agent at Selkirk about her case, and he strongly recommended that if possible Muriel be kept in School for another year.

0337 Juliette Wesley - 16 years of age. Juliette is a very pleasant and happy girl, and is doing well in her school grades. She herself is not anxious to leave School just yet. Last week Inspector Hamilton was here enquiring about this girl. Her mother had seen him with the request that she remain in School, and Inspector Hamilton recommended that she might stay.

495 Edwin Smith - 16 years of age. Edwin stands as the most responsible boy we have in School. He is a boy of good physique, enters well into sports, carries his work diligently, and is the best student that we have. He is taking grade 10 and is anxious to go on to Collegiate this following year and take his grade 11. He has no home to which to go though his father is living and working in Hodgson. Edwin is anxious to make of himself something else than a farmer, and we feel if he has the opportunity he will do so; and I am making a strong plea that he be allowed to return next year and attend Collegiate.

509 Victor Stevenson - 16 years of age. Victor is taking his grade 8 this year, and while he has done well with his studies, he is more for mechanical work. I had a letter from his parents asking if he could come back next year and take a course at the Brandon Technical School. This is a 2-years course. His parents agree to pay his Technical School tuition fees, and any expenses thereto. I would recommend that he be allowed to do this.

450 Orton Plett - 16 years of age. Orton has done well in the classroom, taking his grade 8 this year, and is recommended by the teacher as a good student. He takes his place well in the other activities and work of the School. I have received a letter from his parents asking if he might be able to stay next year and take his grade 9 with us. I recommend that he be allowed to do so.

Trusting that the above will meet with your full approval,

Yours very truly,

Ottawa,
June 4, 1942.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 28th ultimo, and we have very carefully considered the list of pupils in the Brandon Residential School who you consider might remain for another year. In reviewing this list we have kept in mind the demand for female labour, both for farm work and domestic work, throughout the country. At the present time the demand for this far exceeds the supply. Besides, certain conditions which have arisen recently have made it necessary to transfer three, and possibly four, residential schools for purposes other than education of Indian children. As a result, our residential school accommodation will be limited next year and we will likely require all the space we can obtain for orphan and neglected children.

With the above in mind, the following decision has been made:

1. Pupils numbered 0509 and 0553 should be discharged at the end of June;
2. Pupils numbered 0337, 0384 and 0458 may remain for another year only;
3. Pupils numbered 450 and 495 may remain for another year only;
4. Pupil No. 509 may remain for another year only, on the distinct understanding that his parents will pay all his expenses at the technical school. In other words, all that the Department will be required to pay is the annual per capita allowance. If the parents are not prepared to do this, the boy should be discharged at the end of June.

Yours truly,

Rev. R.T. Chapin,
Principal,

Brandon, Man.
