Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 6th instant, with reference to Connie Gaddie, No. 0509. It has been decided to allow her to remain in the Brandon School for another year, in order that she may complete her Grade 12. However, at the present time I am unable to give any definite assurance that we will be able to assist her in attending normal school. The amount of funds at our disposal next year is uncertain, and, besides, we doubt very much the advisability of encouraging Indian girls to study for the teaching profession. Our experience in this particular regard has been unsatisfactory.

With reference to this girl attending high school next year, we will allow the usual advanced educational grant of $50.00 over and above the regular per capita grant.

Dear Sir:

I wish to inform you that I have just had word from Mr. Ring, Commissioner for the Bureau of Child Protection, that he had taken steps to send Jim Keepness and Benny Pasqua to the Brandon Residential School. They were formerly pupils of the File Hills School, but both from the Qu'Appelle Agency, one being from the Muscowpetung Reserve and the other from Pasqua Reserve.

You will recall that I wrote you under date of May 18th our File No. 306-8; 306-11A, advising what had taken place at the trial at Balcarres for the burning of the class rooms. Then you have the Police reports from there. The Police Magistrate issued an order that these boys were to be transferred to Brandon Industrial school.

Mr. Ring informs me that these boys were sent to the school at Brandon and the principal advised the policeman who took them down that he had had no word that they were to be sent to the school. However, they are there now and I wish you would send the approval of our Branch to these boys remaining in the Brandon school for the year, as ordered by the Magistrate.

Yours truly,

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.

Dear Mr. Chapin:

I desire to refer to your letter of September 11 and my reply thereto of September 15, 1942.

Regina, September 24, 1942

Dear Sir:

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 133-0-10 of the 15th instant in connection with two Indian boys who were committed to the Brandon school.

In this connection I wish to refer you to my letter No. 306-8/306-11A dated May 11th last, which gave you full information as to what happened at the trial in connection with the fire at the File Hills school. I also wish to refer you to my letter No. 306-8 of September 15th. I would further inform you that the magistrate and the representative of the Attorney General's Department both consulted me and we were all of the opinion that sending these boys to an Indian school was the proper thing to do and would turn out for the best in the long run. When an Indian school was mentioned I thought that probably Brandon was about the best school we have and the boys would learn more during a year there than at any of our other schools.

Memorandum for file:

Correspondence on file 133-0-10 J, during the period April 14, 1932, to October 18, 1932, explains the reasons for our admission of the three children mentioned in the first part of letter of October 23, 1942, from the Children's Aid Society, Brandon, Man.

A review of the correspondence in 1932 indicates that, while the Department did accept the three children, it was with considerable misgivings, as we were extremely doubtful if they were eligible for admission as grant-earning pupils to an Indian residential school. Shortly after the admission of the three children to the Brandon School, the mother commenced to bother the Principal by insisting on the children being allowed home for holidays and in other ways. As a result, the Department took advantage of her interference to discharge the children from the school in September, 1932. Consequently, the children were only in the school for a period of two or three months and at no time did we make a definite ruling that they were actually our wards.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
October 23rd 1942.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Re: Saito family

The above mentioned family is as follows.

Father - John Saito, born 1887 at Yokohama, Japan.

Mother - Ruby Saito, maiden name Harris, 9-6-1897, born at Brandon, a treaty Indian. This couple were married in Brandon by the Rev. J. Magrath of the Church of England on 24-3-24.

Children - Charles, 5-9-1916
          Thomas, 22-5-1919
          Dolly, 19-12-1923
          Patrick, 2-6-25
          Chester, 2-10-27
          James, 11-2-29
          Elsie, 15-6-31
          John, 3-2-33
          Buna, age 7
          Jerry, age 5
          Norma, age 3.

The first three of these children, Charles, Thomas and Dolly were illegitimate. Charles is now in the Armed Services, Thomas died about a year ago and Dolly is married and away from home. In July or August of 1932, these three children were placed...
Mr. R. A. Hoey  
October 23rd 1942.

In the Indian Residential School in Brandon through the agency of the Brandon Juvenile Court and the Children's Aid Society, Mrs. Saito evidently retained her treaty Indian rights at this time as the children were admitted upon the authority of the Department of Indian Affairs.

Sometime about the middle of September 1932 the Department of Indian Affairs withdrew from their agreement to keep these children at the Brandon Indian Residential School. As there had been considerable friction between the school and the mother and as she had been urging the children to run away, they were allowed to return to the home under the supervision of the Children's Aid Society.

As you can see the family has increased steadily since that time and the remainder of the children listed above are legitimate. It is very doubtful however whether Mr. Saito is the father of all, most, or any of these children.

During the past ten years the Children's Aid Society has received continual complaints from various sources regarding the welfare of these children. School teachers, public health nurses, neighbors, the Medical Health Officer, have all repeatedly complained about the conduct of these children, and inattention at school and the neglect of them by their mother. Mrs. Saito, although it evidently cannot be proven in Court, is known as a prostitute. It is impossible to get any cooperation from her in any manner whatsoever which would lead to the betterment of conditions of the children. The Children's Aid Society is prepared to apprehend these children as neglected children and to take legal custody of them. This is difficult however as these children must then be removed from their home. Because of the nationality of these children we find it impossible to make any arrangements for foster home care for them in private homes. The Children's Shelter in Brandon is only used as a clearing house for children with a maximum stay of three months being provided by law.
Mr. R. A. Hoey  
October 23rd 1942.

We are therefore in the dilemma of being anxious to assist these children but of being without resources to solve the problem.

I have spoken to the Superintendents of the Indian Residential Schools at Brandon and at Birtle regarding the admission of the Salto children to those institutions. Both these men have expressed concern for the welfare of these children but informed me that they could not make an admission of children such as these to their schools without the advice and consent of your Department.

We are therefore anxious to secure your permission for the admission of these children to one or other of these Indian Residential Schools. If the information which we have provided for you is insufficient, I wish you would write to me and I shall endeavour to get whatever extra you may deem necessary.

Awaiting a reply at your earliest convenience,

Yours very truly,

CHILDREN'S AID SOCIETY OF WESTERN MANITOBA.

KIRKLEY, Broadview, Sask., who had stated that he would keep Cecil REDSTAR in his care until an escort arrived from Brandon. Arrangements were also made by R. T. Station advising that he was enroute to Regina, Sask., on escort duty and that he left the necessary particulars at his detachment with regards to locating W. J. KIRKLEY, Indian agent, as he had Cecil REDSTAR in his custody.

Indian Boys concerned:
(a) Donnie THOMAS - age 12; Brandon Indian Residential School, Brandon, Man.

(c) Willis ROYAL - age 11; Brandon Indian Residential School, Brandon, Man.
(d) Lawrence DOOTA - age 12; do.

At 6:35 P.M. of the above date a phone call was received at this detachment from R. T. CHAPIN, Principal of the Brandon Indian Residential School advising that four Indian boys were on a C.P.R. freight heading west and that it was believed that they would get off some in Oak Lake, Man., he wished to know if I could check the freight on its arrival in Oak Lake, he further informed me that the freight in question was passing through Griswold, Man., at the time he was phoning. I informed him that I could not get to Oak Lake in time but that I would contact some person there with the view of having them watch for the Indian Boys and that I would check the freight on its arrival in Virden.

I immediately got in touch with E. D. ALDER, Esq., Oak Lake, and he informed me that he would have someone watch the freight on its arrival, later while I was at the C.P.R. station in Virden I received a phone call from Mr. E. D. ALDER advising that the four Indian Boys had gotten off the freight, that one had been caught and that the other three had run away. I requested that the boy be held and advised that we would leave for Oak Lake immediately.

Patrol per P.C. 8037 accompanied by Sgt. H. B. Luross left Virden immediately for Oak Lake, on arrival it was learned that R. T. CHAPIN, Principal of Brandon Indian Residential School together with an assistant had been in Oak Lake, previous to our arrival, that they had picked up the indian boy being held there and that they had then proceeded east to Griswold via their own transport, as they anticipated that the three Indian boys still at large were being held east with a view of getting onto the Oak River Indian Reserve north of that point. Enquiries were made for various persons in Oak Lake and a patrol of the town failed to reveal any trace of the run away boys, in view of this patrol returned to Virden.

On our arrival in Virden it was learned that Mr. E. D. ALDER, had endeavoured to contact us by phone several times since leaving Oak Lake. At 9:45 P.M. phone call was received at this detachment from Mr. ALDER to the effect that the three Indian Boys were located and that they

6. Patrol per P.C. 6057 accompanied by Cst. H.B. JONES was again made to Oak Lake. W. WHITCOMBE was contacted and the Indian boys taken into our care. In view of this fact patrol was made with the Indian boys to Griswold however all enquiries failed to reveal the whereabouts of the members of the staff at the Brandon Indian School.

7. Previous to leaving Oak Lake, the matron of Brandon Indian School was contacted by phone and advised of the present whereabouts of the boys in question. At approximately 10:00 p.m., this date, phone call was received from Cliff Armstrong, Burrows District farmer, advising that a young Indian had called at his farm for a meal. The Indian was suffering from the effects of the sub-zero weather and had told Armstrong he ran away from the Brandon Indian School last Saturday.

In communication with P.J.B. Kerley, Indian Agent at this point, he advised no notification had been received by him from the School. Later, Mr. Kerley contacted the School and subsequently requested that the Police pick up the Indian and hold him for an escort from Brandon.

Patrol was made via Chev. Odo 6444, accompanied by Sgt. Livingston, to the Burrows Dist., where the Indian was located and brought back to the detachment, arriving here approximately 2:00 a.m. He was held until 5:30 p.m., of the 13-1-43, when R.T. Chaplin, Principal of the School, arrived via CPR. PASQU was handed over to Mr. Chaplin and receipt obtained which is on file at this detachment.

PASQU stated he was 16 years old on Nov. 9th 1942.

Cpl. O.C. "F" Division, Regina. Reg.No.11296. R.S. Miller.

Re: Oliver SPENCE, "et al" (Juveniles) Runaway Boys from the Brandon Indian Residential School, Brandon, Man.

Headquarters:
With reference to the above I have to report that in the name of the 10th inst., a telephone call was received from R.T. GRAFIEK, Principal of the Indian Residential School, Brandon, Man., to the effect two boys had left the school in the name of the 9th inst., and it was thought they had gone to the Minto Dist., with one Noah WILLIAMS, age 17 years, an Indian boy who had left the school previously and who had been working for one SCHREIBER of the Minto Dist., at which place he had left his suitcase. If the boys were located R.T. GRAFIEK desired that they be returned to the Indian School, Brandon, Man.

Sub Division:
Brandon
438 37-2

Detachment:
Beloeuvain,
M-1-13,

The description of the boys was given as follows:
(a) Oliver SPENCE, Age 16 years, Height 5'6", Weight 135 lbs., was wearing gum rubber, blue overalls, brown coat and black leather cap.
(b) Benny BASQUE, Age 16 years, Height 5'6", Weight 142 lbs., was dressed similar to SPENCE with exception BASQUE was wearing a blue sweater.

Owing to the fact Beloeuvain Col. Car was in the garage for repairs, S.P. GRAFIEK, C.M.S., L. Killammy, Supt., was contacted in the early name of the 11th inst., and accompanied by S.P. GRAFIEK per Col. Car Code 1910, a patrol was made to the Margaret and Minto Dist., where the matter was investigated. It was ascertained the mother of Noah WILLIAMS, Mrs. Radio PALKERT was working with her husband at the farm of Orlando SCHREIBER of the Margaret Dist., Mrs. PALKERT was interviewed and stated her son Noah, accompanied by SPENCE, called at her house at approx. 9 p.m. on the night of the 9th inst., having come to Minto by bus from Brandon the same night. Mrs. PALKERT then stated her son had no money she gave him a five dollar bill and he then left saying SPENCE and himself were going to Beloeuvain to look for jobs. The farm premises of Orlando SCHREIBER of the Margaret Dist., were then visited but it was ascertained Noah WILLIAMS had not been working there. The farm premises of Kelvin SCHREIBER of the Minto Dist., were visited when it was ascertained Noah WILLIAMS had been working there but to-date he had not returned for his suitcase. Paul SCHREIBER, Storekeeper of Minto, Man., was interviewed and stated Noah WILLIAMS and another Indian boy got off the Brandon bus on Saturday night the 9th inst., and came into his store. At that time WILLIAMS informed him he was going to visit his mother, Margarette (Mrs.) HALLIVS, Boarding House Proprietor and Bus Agent of Minto, Man., was then interviewed and stated Noah WILLIAMS purchased two single tickets with a five dollar bill for Brandon, Man., on Sunday night the 10th inst., and both he and another...
Indian boy got on the bus for Brandon, Man., Noah WILLIAMS informed him GRAVIS they were going to Brandon to look for jobs.

4. It is respectfully requested R.T. CHAPIN, Principal of the Indian Residential School, Brandon, Man., may be advised Oliver SPENCE was the only boy who came to the Minto Dist., and he returned to Brandon, Man., by bus on Sunday night the 16th inst., in company with Noah WILLIAMS.

5. A copy of this report has been forwarded to the Cpl. 1/c Killarney Det., for his information.

FORWARDED. The request contained in para. 4 has been complied with and Mr. Chapin advises that it is possible Oliver Spence may visit his mother at 24 Martha St., Winnipeg. Benny Basque's home is at Muscow, Sask.

2. Might I suggest that enquiries be made at 24 Martha St., Winnipeg, re Oliver Spence, and if not located, particulars regarding both boys circulated, please. Benny Basque apparently having gone his own way.

3. Brandon Det. personnel are familiar with the absence of these boys from the Indian School, as are the Brandon City Police, and so date nothing is known of their present whereabouts. Extra copies (2) attached.

FORWARDED, 16-1-43, for your information.

Enquiries for these boys are being made in Winnipeg and at Muscow, Sask.

February 1, 1943.

The Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

I beg to enclose, herewith, application forms for the admission of the Tanner children, named below, to the Brandon Residential School. Both children are under the age of admission as grant earning pupils, however, I would advise that they are being kept by one Mike Swain under Department authority, at a cost of $7.50 per month. The children are not as well kept as they would be in school, and the Principal of Brandon has no objection to their admission as he has two or three children of approximately the same age. The reason the Indian wants his children at Brandon is that his wife is in Mental Hospital there and he visits her from time to time. He could visit his children at the same time.

There is also a girl at Portage School, Emma Tanner, No. 0285. The Principal of the Portage School would have no objection to the transfer of this pupil to Brandon, as this would allow all the children of this family to be together.

The admissions enclosed cover the two children—Joseph Stanley Tanner and George-aileen Tanner.

I beg to recommend admission of the two pupils above noted and the transfer of Emma Tanner to the Brandon School.

J. Waite,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ontario.

Re: Pupils for Brandon School.

I have your letter dated January 29th re the above matter.

Unfortunately this school has never seemed to have a very definite recruiting ground. Griswold Agency has one day school and the boarding school children are divided between the Lehret, Elkhorn and Brandon Schools.

On the Birtle Agency the children attend the Birtle School, Sandy Bay or Pine Creek.

Swan Lake Reserve has a day school and a few attend Portage. Long Plain children practically all go to Portage. Roseau River is divided between Portage and the Fort Alexander School. The Lake Reserves have day schools and a few pupils are recruited for Elkhorn and Pine Creek. The Brokenhead Reserve has a day school, but a few pupils attend the Brandon School.

In the past Brandon secured some pupils from the reserve at Carlyle, Sintaluta, the Crooked Lakes Agency, Wood Mountain south of Saskatoon, and a few from around Prince Albert.

The Fisher River Agency send a few pupils to Brandon; but we have five good teachers on this Agency and naturally the parents prefer to have the children home.

I am writing the Agents concerned in Manitoba requesting that they give this matter their special attention, and if they can find any neglected child or children not attending school to arrange for their physical examination and have them admitted to Brandon. I, however, am of the opinion that the best and most satisfying recruiting can be done by the Principals themselves. A trip in the summer to the various reserves establishes a real connection with the home life and the Indians naturally like to meet the one who supervises the care of their children. Mr. Chapin speaks the Indian language well and I am sure a little time spent by him in recruiting would bear good returns.

A.G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies for Manitoba.

Oliver SPENCE, et al., (Juveniles), Runaway boys from the Brandon Indian Residential School, Brandon, Man.

1. Relative to the above and further to previous reports submitted in this connection I beg to report that on the 29-1-43, Oliver SPENCE was apprehended on the Pogris Indian Reserve by members of this detachment.

560 Harry Kay - Harry came from Round Lake School last year and has proved one of our most diligent students, backed up by a very fine disposition. 567 Billy Queskekapow - Billy was sent from Norway House last year where he had completed his grade 8 in the day school. Billy has been making good progress in his grade 9 this year. 0431 Frances Wesley - Frances is only in grade 5 though she is 16 years of age. She did not get started to school very early. Her parents are not living on the reserve and the Agent concurred in my opinion that it would be better for the girl to remain in school for another year.

In reply to your letter 133-0-10, dated the 13th inst., in connection with the Applications for Admittance to Brandon Residential School of Agnes Thomas and Nelson Linklater.

Agnes Thomas is the daughter of a man who was discharged from the army this medically unfit. He is not well now and cannot support his family. Nelson Linklater's father is away from Nelson House practically all the time trapping, and the family goes with him. The boy has very little opportunity of attending the Day School. This applies to quite a number of the Nelson House Indians, and it would be better for the children if they were sent to a Residential School. However, the parents are not willing to let them go. You will remember that the Department sent me a letter during the past year, saying that the Brandon School could take more pupils and if there were not any children in this Agency who should be sent there. I informed the Indians of this but very few were willing to allow their children to go to a residential school that was so far away.

The above named children are already in Brandon School and the school have already incurred considerable expense in connection with them. I recommend that they be left in school and admitted as grant earning pupils.

S. Lovell,
Indian Agent.

Mr. S. Lovell, Indian Agent, The Pas, Manitoba.

Dear Sir:

Re: Elijah SINCLAIR, 24,
Fisher River Band,
KOOSTATAK, Man.

This young man has been a patient here at Fisher River Hospital, since March 2, 1942, with tuberculous disease of the right hip-joint. This has reacted well to treatment, and Elijah is now gradually increasing walking and other exercise, with a view to ultimate discharge. His hip is quite firmly fixed, though in a position which permits a moderately normal gait.

Unfortunately, it is unlikely that Elijah could trap, hunt, fish, or do bush work for his livelihood without a breakdown. He is fortunate in having a Grade X, (Manitoba) education, and would like to finish High School, and possibly Grade XII and teach.

If the Department could arrange for Elijah to attend Brandon Residential School, I am sure that the institution would find him a definite asset in these days when competent assistance is so hard to obtain. We have found him a great help in managing our younger patients and I am sure the School would find him a similar asset in assisting with supervision and the like.

A small sum in the way of salary would help Elijah with his own educational expenses and would definitely be money well spent.

May I recommend that Elijah's case receive your special consideration. I should be very glad to hear the Department's decision.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir,

In reply to letter of the 10th (133-0-10) in reference to Elijah Sinclair and the suggestion of his working in the School and at the same time taking his Grade XII.

Inspector Hamilton was to be in Brandon so I left the matter over to talk with him as I did not exactly agree with Dr. Ridge's suggestion as you have interpreted it. I am in hearty accord with Elijah coming here to finish his High School work and then taking his Normal. I believe that wherever there is ability and the will to work the opportunity ought to be given to make something of it. Grade XII is not necessary for Normal. Elijah could come here and take his Grade XI in the Brandon Collegiate. His progress in that grade could determine his ability to go on further. Being out of school for some time he might require two years to get his Grade XI. But I do not think the idea of taking employment in the School while studying is sound. There is very little time to do any work of account. The truck leaves the School at 8.30 in the morning taking the children in and it is about 4.45 when they get back in the afternoon. The Collegiate pupils have considerable home work to do, which they must attend to if they are to make progress. Saturday would be the only spare time he would have to speak of. Anyway, the pupils in the school are expected to do certain duties to be helpful.

I would suggest that Elijah be sent to the School as a regular grant-earning pupil, with the usual extra grant for Collegiate pupils (Collegiate fees and $50.). Whatever spare time he has to be used remuneratively will be recognized.

yours truly,

Dear Sir:

Once again I am forced to call upon you for assistance in a very vital matter. The facts of the case have to do with some of my children which have been left with me to look after, my wife having left my bed and board.

The problem at present is how I am going to place the three eldest in a place which will do the most good to them. I had in mind trying to get them admitted into the Indian Residential School at Brandon, of which institution myself and wife are former pupils. The difficulty, however, seems to hinge around these children not being treaty Indians. Both myself and wife were treaty Indians at the time we were pupils there and there were then quite a number of children who were not in treaty. However, the restrictions must have been tightened up somewhat. I am of the opinion however that the thing could be swung around in my favour, with a helping from you. Mr. A. G. Hamilton, Inspector of Indian Agencies is forwarding a request to Ottawa in regard to the case.

I have five (5) children on my hands right now, and as I mentioned I would very much like to get the three (3) eldest, a girl of 13, boy of 11, girl of 7, off my hands. The two youngest ages 4 & 2 years, both boys (Robert & Ralph), I would put in care of a friend of mine.

I am sure you can do a lot in this matter so will leave it to you.

Yours truly,

"R. J. McKenny"

Both myself and wife are now enfranchised.

Dear Mr. Haybank:

Mr. M. Christianson, Gen. Supt. of Indian Agencies,
Dominion Public Bldg., Searth & Victoria, Regina, Sask.

I have your letter of the 29th ultimo, with reference to Lloyd Francis, No. 511, and Hugh Francis, No. 518, of the Brandon Residential School.

In view of your statement that the father is in a position to support his children and send them to school in Regina the Department approves of their discharge from the Brandon Residential School. It is regretted, however, that this matter was not brought to our attention previously, because, in fairness to the management of the Brandon School, they should have been notified some weeks ago.

With reference to the last paragraph of your letter, I agree that from information we have received it would appear that there should be plenty of children for all the residential schools. I believe this statement applies at the present time to the Brandon School.

Dear Mr. Christianson:

Re: Amelek Roberts and Adam Bird
Juvenile Delinquents, Montreal Lake

On September 18, 1944 the above juvenile delinquents were committed to the Industrial School for an indefinite period for unlawfully and cruelly ill-treating a horse in such a manner as to cause it unnecessary suffering or injury, contrary to Section 542 of the Criminal Code of Canada. One of these boys has no knowledge whatsoever of English although they have got along as well as can be expected in the Industrial School. They are definitely out of their element and I feel that if they can be transferred to the Indian School at Brandon or some similar institution that far greater progress could be made with them. They do not appear to be bad boys and I do not believe would give the authorities in any school to which they were admitted, undue trouble. I am wondering, therefore, if it would be possible for the Indian Department to arrange such a transfer.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

I am herewith forwarding a letter received from the Director of the Child Welfare Branch, Mr. K.S. Armstrong.

This is in connection with juvenile delinquents from Montreal Lake. You will have the police reports in Ottawa where these two boys were sent to the Industrial School here for mistreating a horse in such a manner as to cause it unnecessary suffering contrary to Section 542 of the Criminal Code of Canada.

You will note what Mr. Armstrong has to say about these boys being transferred to the Brandon School or some other Indian institution of that kind. You will further note Mr. Armstrong states one of the boys has no knowledge of English whatsoever.

I went over to see Mr. Armstrong a few days ago as there were several matters he wanted to discuss with me. It was he, however, who suggested sending the boys to the Brandon School. He is acquainted with the Indian schools having been at one time missionary amongst the Indians with the Methodist Church in northern Manitoba.

I hope you will give this matter due consideration.

Mr. M. Christianson, Gen. Supt. of Indian Agencies,
Dominion Public Bldg., Searth & Victoria, Regina, Sask.

I have your letter of the 23rd ultimo, with reference to Amelek Roberts and Adam Bird. I note your suggestion that they be sent to the Brandon Residential School. In this regard I may say that we have had reports that during the past year the discipline at this school was not all that could be desired. Recently a new Principal has taken charge and we are hopeful that he will be able to control the discipline. However, at the present time we hesitate to send two other boys, who might prove to be problem cases. Is there no Protestant school in the province of Saskatchewan in which these boys could be placed? I should appreciate your giving the matter further thought and writing to me again. I may add that Reverend Mr. Ellis, Principal of the St. Alban's School at Prince Albert, was in the Department last week and it is evident from what he says that that particular school cannot accommodate additional pupils at the present time.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Sir:

Miss Winnifred Goforth, who has been attending High School in Balcarres for the past two months, wishes to apply for a transfer to Brandon Indian School. During this time she has been rather unhappy in her association with white children and has not received proper supervision while there. Her parents feel that she needs the supervision provided by a residential school and are very much in favor of the change. I have been in communication with Principal Strapp of Brandon and he is quite willing that she be enrolled at his school, as he is short of pupils at the present time.

I would be pleased, Mr. Simpson, if you would take this matter up with the Department with a view to having the necessary permission granted.

Yours very truly,

L. L. Dobbin

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 133-0-10 of the 1st instant in connection with Amelek Roberts and Adam Bird who are in the Industrial School here.

In reply I took up the matter of their admittance with the File Hills School at Balcarres and I also took up the matter with the Reverend Mr. Badham who is Secretary of the Synod of the Diocese of Qu'Appelle to try to have them admitted to the Gordon's School but both schools have refused to admit them. The St. Alban's School in Prince Albert, I believe, is crowded to the roof therefore it is out of the question to send them there. Furthermore the Round Lake School is overcrowded and the only other Protestant institution in this province is the Lac La Ronge School. The only way we could send the boys there would be by aeroplane and as you know, the discipline there is rather lax.

I believe there is room for these boys in the Brandon School and I feel sure that the Reverend Mr. Strapp, the Principal there, could handle them because I became acquainted with him when he was in Ottawa. In view of this I would ask you to again consider sending these boys to the Brandon School, and I would appreciate a reply as soon as possible. I have informed Mr. Armstrong that I am unable to get the boys into any Protestant Boarding School in this province and that I have therefore referred the matter back to Ottawa.

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.
Ottawa, December 19, 1944.

Dear Mr. Strapp:

Two Indian boys from the Montreal Lake Reserve were recently placed in the Industrial School at Regina for unlawfully and cruelly ill-treating a horse in such a manner as to cause it unnecessary suffering or injury, contrary to Section 542 of the Criminal Code of Canada. One of these boys has no knowledge of English and both of them are reported to be out of their element at the white industrial school and officials feel that they should be placed in an Indian residential school. We would be pleased if you would accept them at Brandon, as I believe they would make more progress with you than at the institution in which they have been placed. Their names and ages are:

Amelek Roberts, age 16
Adam Bird, age 13.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Principal,

There is a matter regarding runaway children from Indian Residential Schools upon which I would like your advice.

During the nearly eight years in which I have been here, I have cooperated in every possible way in returning the runaway children to their schools. This has been no small job at times either.

The principals of nearby schools sit in their office, telephone me that some children have run away, and ask me to round up these children and see that they return to school. I have always rounded them up, but personally I feel that when these Residential Schools take charge of the children, it is their duty to get out themselves and round up their absent pupils.

Would you kindly advise just what my duties are in these cases, and what are the duties of the Principal?

W. Young,
Indian Agent
Ottawa, February 19, 1945.

Mr. W. Young, Indian Agent, Griswold, Manitoba.

I have your letter of the 12th instant, with reference to returning truant children to Indian residential schools.

For your information, I enclose copies of circular letters of May 6, 1941, and June 21, 1942. A review of these two letters indicates the Department's wishes, and, in brief, it may be said that we expect full co-operation between all our officials in returning truant pupils. You will note, in the third paragraph of circular letter of May 6, 1941, that principals are expected to put forth every effort to return absentee pupils before calling on Indian agents and other officials to assist them. At the same time, as stated in the circular letter, and as mentioned above, we expect our officials to co-operate with one another.

It is realized that there are certain seasons of the year when Indian agents and farming instructors are particularly busy, especially in connection with farming activities, and at such periods of the year principals should only expect the minimum of help from agents and farming instructors.

Encl.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Mr. Phelan;

In reply to your letter of the above noted date and file number may I say that I am sorry that this matter has hung on so long. It was hanging fire for a considerable period before I left Muncey. I am enclosing the copy of my letter dated July 2nd, in reply to your inquiry of June 29, 1945.

Our registration is not by any means where I would like to see it as we only have 127 registered at September last. There is a number of children on the reserve at Carlyle, Sask., who should be in school. I went up to see what could be done about it last Monday but did not get any satisfaction, other than "When a teacher is appointed we will see what can be done" from Mr. J.R. Morrison, the Farm Instructor. There will be a surplus above the rating of the school there of about 20 children for whom no accommodation can be made. I felt that some effort should be made to get this group lined up for us as when the matter is allowed to drift we lose per capita grant that we need, as our overhead is running on all the while, and the children, when they do arrive, are so far behind in their work that they disrupt the classes seriously by their late entrance.

Mr. Kerley has promised to get in touch with me when he can make any arrangements to send the children down.

A line to our Toronto office might speed things up a little, I think that Mrs. Loveys is the secretary concerned.

Yours truly,

The following parties are concerned with in this file:

Elizabeth COCKRANE, age 17 yrs., Margaret CRATE, age 16 yrs., Margaret MASON, age 16 yrs., and Shirley MASON, age 15 yrs., c/o Brandon Industrial School, Brandon, Manitoba.

In the above connection, I have to report on this date information was received from Miss Margaret COCKRANE, teacher, Brandon Indian Residential School, to the effect that the above four girls were missing from that point, and were last seen on the school grounds at 4:45 P.M. the 10th inst. Miss COCKRANE further stated she had been informed that these girls had been seen at No 2 AGA, Station, Brandon, Man., approx. 9:00 P.M. the 10th inst., and it is believed they were intending to go to Fisher River reserve, Man., to their homes. At this time Miss COCKRANE stated the Indian Agent, Fisher River reserve, Man., had been advised, and he was notifying the girls' parents. Brandon City Police had also been advised.

A description of the missing girls was obtained and this information was passed on to Carberry Town Station, who were requested to advise Portage la Prairie detachment. Minnedosa detachment was also advised.

This A.M. Mr. O.B. STAFF, Principal, Brandon Indian Residential School was contacted by the writer and stated he had heard that all girls were working in a cafe in Winnipeg, washing dishes. Other enquiries made in Brandon detachment area has failed to give any lead.

The following is a description of the missing girls:

(1) Elizabeth COCKRANE - 17 yrs., 5 ft., 7", 117 lbs., black hair, wearing brown oxfords, blue dress and brown jacket, very dark appearance.

(2) Margaret CRATE - 16 yrs., 5 ft., 6", 121 lbs., reddish brown hair, freckled face, wearing blue dress and brown jacket, and brown oxfords.

(3) Margaret MASON - 16 yrs., 5 ft., 96 lbs., dark hair, pink and blue dress, green sweater and white running shoes.

(4) Shirley MASON - 15 yrs., 5 ft., 104 lbs., mousey colored hair, blue dress, light grey jacket, brown oxford shoes.

May a description of the four above girls be circularized please. File is being concluded as hereunder at this detachment. Extra copies attached.

Relative to the above I have to report that on the 20-10-45, whilst in the Fisher River District, Man., in connection with other duty, enquiries were made as to the whereabouts of Margaret and Shirley Mason, the missing Indian girls.

It was ascertained that while both these girls had been stopping with their father, Percy Mason, at Birch Point, Lake Winnipeg, Man., they had come out to Fisher River for a few days, and had left again, going out on the Lake, and no definite information could be obtained as to what Island or camp they had gone to.

The fishing season on Lake Winnipeg ends on the 27-10-45, when it is expected that these girls and their father will return to Fisher River, Man., when they will be apprehended and escorted to Winnipeg.

Due to the fact that it was impossible to obtain transportation during the past month and as the ice is as yet not solid enough for travelling I would respectfully request that Diary Date in this connection be set to 20-12-45, by which time it is hoped that a patrol can be made to Birch Point. With reference to the above, on this date information was received at this detachment from J.R. Morrison, Farm Instructor, White Bear Indian Reserve, to the effect that the above mentioned juveniles had run away from the Brandon Indian Residential School, and he believed that they had now arrived back on the White Bear Indian Reserve. They left Brandon, he believed on or about April 13th last. He asked that the boys be returned to the Residential School, stating that it would be useless to follow the procedure sometimes followed, i.e., place the boys on the train and have them return to the school themselves.

Being engaged on other important police duties this date re: John Michael MILDENBERGER & Alfred SHARPE - B.B. & Theft (460) Manor and Milestone, Sask., I was unable to take this matter in hand this date. I advised Mr. Morrison that I would attend to the matter as soon as my duties permitted.

On this date a patrol was made per police auto to the White Bear Indian Reserve, I contacted the Farm Instructor, J.R. Morrison, and he and I together endeavoured to locate the four juveniles, however, they had taken to the bush, and it was next to impossible this date to locate them. Consequently having other matters to attend to, I returned to Carlyle at 4:30 P.M.

On this date a further patrol was made per police auto to the Reserve, accompanied by Const. Mahoney, the juveniles were located and taken into our custody, under the provisions of section 10, sub-section 4 of the Indian Act - they were brought into Carlyle. I contacted the Farm Instructor, and advised him that I had located the four boys in question. The ages of the boys were as follows - Norman 15 years, Howard and David 11 years, and Clifford 13 years.

The farm instructor having advised me that the Principal, The Rev. O.B. Strupp, of the Residential school referred to had requested that the delinquents be returned under escort, due to the fact that he was of the opinion that they would not return themselves.

Further to the above I have to report that on the 6-6-46, whilst on patrol at the Fisher River Hospital, Peguis Indian Reserve, Redden District, Man., information was received from Dr. C.J.W. HICK, M.D., that Shirley BASHO, one of the wanted Indian girls, was confined in the Hospital, having been brought in a few days before by her father, Percy BASHO, Jr. Dr. HICK stated that owing to the girl's condition, she could not be moved from the Hospital for some days, and that he would notify this detachment when she was ready to be discharged, so that she could be apprehended and escorted to Winnipeg.

On the 9-6-46, whilst on patrol on the Peguis Reserve on other duty, information was received that Margaret BASHO, the other wanted Indian girl, was at the Fisher River Hospital, visiting her sister, Shirley BASHO, accompanied by a matron. I immediately patrolled to the Hospital, where Margaret BASHO was taken into custody. I might here mention that on this date, Dr. HICK was not at the Hospital, and the Matron in charge, Miss Jessie HICK, R.N., informed me that she did not know when Shirley BASHO would be fit to leave the Hospital, and could not release her without Dr. HICK's authority, and that as far as she knew, Shirley BASHO might not be permitted to leave the Hospital for some days.

Margaret BASHO was escorted to Winnipeg, where she was lodged in the Manitoba Home for Girls, West Kildonan, Man., receipt being obtained, and same is held on file at this detachment.

On the 10-6-46, Sgt. V.H. JOSEPHSON, i.e. this detachment, whilst on patrol on the Peguis I.R., interviewed Dr. HICK (who had returned) regarding Shirley BASHO. Dr. HICK stated that in view of the fact that this girl would be taken to a place where she could be given the necessary medical attention, he would release her from the Hospital. She was taken into custody by Sgt. Josephson, who, accompanied by a matron, escorted Shirley BASHO to the Manitoba Home for Girls, West Kildonan, Man., where she was handed over to the matron in charge, receipt being obtained as same is held on file at this detachment.

The above noted girls who are the subjects of this file were apprehended by members of the Hudson Detachment on the dates shown, and were escorted to Winnipeg and placed in the Manitoba Home for Girls.

Margaret and Shirley Mason appeared before Juvenile Judge Hamilton in Juvenile Court, Winnipeg, Man., during the afternoon of the 12-6-46 at which time they were remanded and to be held at the Manitoba Home for Girls until 10:30 A.M. of the 17-6-46 in order that they may be medically examined before being returned to the Brandon Indian Residential School. This request and examination being obtained at the request of the Department of Indian Affairs.

This matter has been taken up with Juvenile Judge Hamilton who advised the writer that providing the medical examinations have been completed on the 17-6-46 he will order that the girls be returned to the Brandon Indian Residential School.

A member of the Winnipeg Detachment will attend Juvenile Court on the 17-6-46 in this connection.

FORWARDED 19-6-46 for your information and file record.

When bringing any prisoner to Winnipeg, or person being detained such as this file records, a short covering report should be drafted before leaving Winnipeg to show what has been done.

Dear Mr. Neary:

In reply to your communication of the above noted date and file number, may I say that I have discussed the matter of discharge or continuing their education with all pupils who are not yet taking work above grade VIII and who are 16 years of age or over.

The only pupil who expressed a desire to be discharged was #0430 Elizabeth Cochrane, of the Hodgson Agency, aged 17. Elizabeth has completed grade VIII with a strong recommendation from her teacher for grade IX. However as she is now over 17 years of age and has been offered a position at our Indian hospital at Halfway near Hodgson I suggested to her that she take the position at least for the holiday period and then decide what she really wanted to do about coming back to school.

I feel sure that Elizabeth will decide to stay out of school when September comes and therefore recommend that she be granted the Diploma.

I would be glad to have your opinion as to the advisability or otherwise of confining the recipients of the diplomas to those attaining at least grade VIII.

Ottawa, October 1, 1946.

Dear Mr. Douglas:

In the absence of the Minister I desire to acknowledge the receipt of your telegram of September 28 with reference to Clifford and Verma Shepherd.

Our files show that these two children were admitted to the Brandon Indian Residential School in October, 1943, and the application forms were signed by their father, who presumably desired the children placed in that school.

The June quarter return of the Brandon Residential School shows that the two children were in residence to June 30. At that time, I am informed, they were allowed home for the usual two months' holidays, on the understanding that they would return to the school upon the expiry of their leave, namely, September 1.

We have not received any report regarding these children being returned under escort by the Royal Canadian Mounted Police. We are writing our officials in this matter and when we receive their reply, a further communication will be directed to you.

Mr. J.P.B. Ostrander, Inspector of Indian Agencies,
414 Federal Bldg., REGINA, Sask.

The Department has just received the following telegram from Hon. T.C. Douglas, Premier of Saskatchewan:

"CLIFFORD AND VERNA CHILDREN OF JOHN SHEPHERD OF MOOSE MOUNTAIN RESERVE AT CARLYLE WERE FORCIBLY REMOVED FROM DAY SCHOOL LAST MONDAY BY RCMP AND SENT TO BRANDON INDIAN SCHOOL STOP FATHER AND MEMBERS OF HAND HAVE PROTESTED ARBITRARY ACTION OF AGENT KEARLEY STOP SCHOOL PRINCIPAL AND OSTRANDER REFUSE TO TAKE ACTION TO RESTORE CHILDREN TO RESERVE ALTHOUGH DAY SCHOOL AFFORDS ADEQUATE ACCOMMODATION AND INSTRUCTION STOP THIS MATTER REQUIRES YOUR IMMEDIATE ATTENTION FOR WHICH I THANK YOU STOP LETTER FOLLOWS."

Our files show that these two children were admitted to the Brandon Indian Residential School in October, 1943, and the application forms were signed by the father and approved by Indian Agent Kerley.

The June quarter return of the Brandon Residential School shows that these two children were in residence to June 30th.

From the information contained in the telegram, we presume that these two children were allowed home on holidays and did not return upon the expiry of their leave.

We have not received any request for their discharge from the Brandon School.

The application forms show that Clifford Shepherd, who was born on July 28, 1932, had previously attended the White Bear Day School for three years. If this information was
correct, it would appear that the parents did not bother to send
the child to school until he was eight years of age. Verna
Shepherd was born on January 3, 1936 and was slightly over seven
years of age when sent to Brandon. It was stated on the application
form that she had not attended school previously.

In recommending the admission of these two children to
the Brandon School from a reserve on which there is a Day School,
it is presumed that the Indian Agent considered they required
Institutional care.

We would like to know the distance from the Shepherd's
home to the White Bear School. We would also like to have a
report regarding home conditions. Are the parents in a position
to send the children to the Day School and give them proper care?
On whose instructions were the services of the R.C.M.P. used?

A copy of this letter is being sent to Indian Agent
Kerley in the hope that he will report fully on local conditions
and submit same to you in order that you can forward his letter
together with any comments that you desire to make.

An early reply would be very much appreciated.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

With reference to Department letter of the 2nd instant,
File No. 133-0-10 (W.T.), regarding the telegram received from the Honourable T.C. Douglas, Premier of Saskatchewan, in the matter of "forcibly removing Clifford and Verna Shepherd from the Moose Mountain Reserve to the Brandon Residential School", I am enclosing herewith copy of a report received from Indian Agent Kerley in this connection.

I have little to add to the report of Indian Agent Kerley other than to say that I approve of his action in having these children taken to the Brandon School when it was necessary to employ the R.G.M. Police to return three boys, George Pewean, Howard and Norman Shepherd, to the school after they had run away.

John Shepherd ran away from the Brandon School toward the end of the last school term and he and his sister were intentionally not available when the children were being gathered up for return to the Brandon School at the beginning of this term, therefore it seemed advisable to have the two of them returned at the same time as the truant boys.

I am sure that the Honourable T.C. Douglas would agree that a small house with a Tubercular mother and several small children is not an ideal situation. This is one of the cases where I believe that the residential school gives its best service in relieving a sick mother or some of the work of the home and removing healthy children from daily contact with a tubercular person in a small house. If children from houses of this kind are not justifiably placed in residential schools, whether the father is willing or unwilling, then I believe we have little excuse for continuing to operate residential schools.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

In reply to the above mentioned letter, I beg
to report that Clifford and Verna Shepherd were admitted to
Brandon Residential School in the fall of 1943 at the request
of their father John Shepherd. With the exception of Clifford
running away from the school, the two children have been good
at school. They came home for the summer holidays and did not
return with the other pupils. John Shepherd asked Rev. Fr.
Laviolette if they could attend the St. Francis Day School, he
was told that they would have to be discharged first. However
no application for transfer was requested.

One of the reasons for sending the children to
Brandon in the first place was owing to the bad health of Mrs.
Shepherd, she has T.B. and was a patient at the Fort Qu'Appelle Hospital for nearly a year. There are seven children in
this family and they live in a small house, John is a fair
provider and his wife is a fairly good housekeeper, it is four
miles to the White Bear School and two miles to the St. Francis
School. I believe that all the children of school age in this
family should go to Residential School, unless John builds an
addition to the house or a new and larger one, and hires a girl
to assist his wife. John Shepherd was informed several times
that until the children were discharged they would have to re-
turn to Brandon Residential School.

Three boys, George Pewean, Howard and Norman Shep-
herd ran away from Brandon School and I requested the R.C.M.P.
to escort them back and at the same time to take Clifford and
Verna Shepherd.

W. J. D. Kerley,
Indian Agent.

Patrol continued to the Birdtail Sioux Reserve where this boy was located and who stated that he and one other boy Clifford SHEPHERD had left the School together and had boarded a freight train and at Souris, Man., THOMPSON got off the train to look for SHEPHERD as both had not boarded the same box-car and the train started up and he could not get back on. (1) On the p.m. 4*11*46, word was received at Brandon Det; from Miss Cochran, teacher, Indian Residential School, Brandon, Man; that the following named boys had been reported missing from the school. They had been last seen at 8.30 p.m. 4*11*46.

No.1 Cecil Thompson, age 15 yrs, address, Sintaluta, Sask;
No.2 George Pewson, age 14 yrs, address, Moose Mountain Reserve, Sask;
No.3 David Little-shief, age 14 yrs, address, Moose Mountain Reserve, Sask;
No.4 Clifford Sheford, age 13 yrs, address, Moose Mountain Sask;
No.5 Nelson Thompson, age 13 yrs, address, Sintaluta, Sask;

(2) The above being supplied for information of Detachment members in the event that any of the boys be observed by patrols from the Det; further that all the above mentioned boys were dressed as follows:- Airforce jackets, Tweed caps, Grey and blue shirts, with grey and blue overalls. It was believed that all five youths would endeavour to reach their homes in Saskatchewan.

(3) Brandon City Police Dept, Garberry T.S. Virden Det; and Moosomin Det; were advised of the above. Patrols from Brandon Det; to date have not observed any of the missing Indian youths, but a lookout for them is being continued, by patrols when on other police duties.

(4) Of the above mentioned, Nelson Thompson (No.5) was located by Cst. Hall, Hamiota Det; and returned to the residential school at Brandon. 1. Referring to the above, on this date, with reference to memo dated Winnipeg, Man., Nov 23rd, 1946, minute of the Sept. 1/3 C.E.M.S. Regime, Sack, dated 28-11-46 annexed, and to foot-note of the C.E.M.S. Regime same date. On this date, information having been received that the four boys mentioned in the memo referred to above, had returned to the White Bear Indian Reserve, near Carlyle, Sask., a patrol was made this date per police auto to that point, accompanied by Const. Mahoney.

2. On arrival at the Reserve, only two of the boys could be located i.e., Cecil THOMPSON and Clifford SHEPPARD, referred to as SHIFORD - in the memo.

3. Some four hours was spent in trying to locate the other two delinquents, without result, they were well aware that we were awaiting their return from the bush, it being impossible to follow them, due to the numerous trails in the bush, and having no idea in which direction they had travelled, and also to the exceptionally heavy condition of the roads over which we had to travel. I was forced to abandon the search for the two boys, and be content with the two I had located, for the time being.

4. The farm instructor was notified of the locating of the two boys mentioned, and he will be on the lookout for the other two, who apparently took to the bush, as soon as our presence on the reserve was learned.

5. Patrol returned to Carlyle at 4:30 P.M., this date, and left again at 5:30 P.M., enroute to Brandon, Man.; upon arrival the two boys were handed over to the matron at the Brandon Indian Residential school. Patrol left Brandon at 10:30 A.M. 29-11-46, intending to return to Carlyle, but due to the difficult driving conditions, upon arrival at Souris, Man., the patrol was abandoned, and remained at that point for the balance of the night.

29-11-46.

6. Patrol left Souris at 9:10 A.M., this date, attending to other police duties at Redvers, Sask., enroute, patrol eventually returned to Carlyle at 1 P.M.

7. Further investigation is to be carried out, in conjunction with Provincial Secretary's Office and David Littlechild.

PREMIER'S OFFICE

Regina, December 11, 1946.

Honorable J. A. Glen,
Minister of Mines and Resources,
House of Commons,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Mr. Glen:

On September 27th I telegraphed you with respect to the case of Clifford and Verma, children of John Shepherd of Moose Mountain Indian Reserve at Carlyle, who were removed from a day school which they had been attending at that reserve and sent, under police escort, to the Brandon Indian School.

On October 1st, your secretary, Mr. W.J.F. Pratt, wrote to me, setting out certain facts relating to the case of these children, and a further letter was sent on October 15th. It was there pointed out that in view of the home conditions of these children, it was in their best interests to be enrolled in a residential school.

Since receiving this communication, I have heard further from representatives of this Reserve who have advised me that the boy, Clifford, has again run away from the Brandon Residential School and returned home by hitch hiking and on foot. I understand that he travelled through a severe blizzard and returned home ill-clothed and in a weakened condition. I understand, also, that two boys, being the sons of Jim Thompson of the Indian Reserve at Sintaluta, have also run away from the Brandon school, and these incidents have caused grave concern among the Indians of the district. The information which they receive is to the effect that the children in the Brandon Residential School are not properly cared for, that they do not receive sufficient supervision or training, and that the food is inadequate.

With particular regard to the case of the Shepherd children,

I had considerable trouble, after the constable left us, with Clifford and eventually had to use force to put him in the dormitory of the school.

I do not think that either George Pewan or David Littlechief should be returned to this school as they have always been a source of trouble from their first year in school. Some of the Albert schools are in need of pupils, especially Edmonton, and perhaps they might do better if transferred there.

Apparently Mr. Strapp is under the impression that Clifford Shepherd should be sent to some other residential school as he is unable to handle him. I do not know of any school which I would recommend for this purpose and I do not like to transfer a boy from one residential school to another by way of punishment as this may lead the parents to look upon residential schools as houses of correction.

It would also appear to me that Mr. Strapp wishes to be relieved of responsibility for these boys who have been troublesome, and either return them to the reserve for the Departmental officials to worry about or transfer them to another school principal for the same purpose. A residential school under good management does not usually have a great deal of trouble with the boys. Dear Sir;

I am in receipt of your communication of the above noted date and file number, with the enclosures.

I beg to report as follows:

I am informed by reliable Indians from the Moose Mountain Reserve, Sask., that the trouble with the John Shepherd family has originated from the activities of the teacher and other interested parties connected with the recently instituted R.C. Day School on that reserve.

I am informed that a number of the people were persuaded to move from their usual place of abode to the vicinity of the new school during the past summer. When school opened in September, without consulting either the Indian Agent or the resident Farm Instructor, pupils from certain Residential Schools were registered and attended classes. As the method of the registration was irregular these pupils were returned to their respective schools under escort.

No. 585 Clifford Shepherd and his sister No. 0578 were returned to Brandon on September 24th.

Clifford has been absent without leave as follows:

October 9th, about 8.00 A.M. taking with him a new pupil Victor Bruce. They were returned by R.C.M.P. escort on October 11th.
November 4th, in company with George Pewan and David Little-Chief. Returned November 28th by R.C.M.P.

December 3rd, Miss. Cochrane, the Matron, reported that Clifford and two other boys, Kenneth Sammey and Davis Shepherd, were missing. I immediately got out the car and drove out #1 highway, west from Brandon for about 10 miles, making inquiry at various farm houses along the way. I did not get any trace of the boys and returned to the school. About 2:30 P.M. I received a telephone call to the effect that three boys were walking along the Canadian Pacific Railway about 1 mile from Kennay. I called the R.C.M.P. and the officer in charge sent a constable out with me. We located the boys and after some time were able to get down the line to them. On the return trip I left the constable at his headquarters and returned with the boys to the school. Just as we entered the school Clifford made an attempt to run away again and put up quite a fight. I was compelled to use considerable force to remove him to the dormitory. About a week later Clifford told Davis Shepherd to get ready to run away with him again. Davis confided in Kenneth Sammey and tried to persuade him to go with them. Kenneth did not want to go and so came to my office and made a report of the matter.

I am enclosing a copy of a letter I addressed to Mr. Agent Kerley, of Broadview, Sask.

With reference to the charges of lack of supervision, poor instruction, and inadequate food; the boys are given about 4 hours a day of free time during which they are permitted to attend their trap lines, go sleighing and skating, or play games and read periodicals in their reading room. On Saturday afternoons they are permitted to visit Brandon to sell their pelts, do shopping, or attend the theatres.

The complaint is made and has been made since residential schools were first instituted that the food is inadequate. My reply to this complaint is "look at the children". In this connection I have prepared a list, from our card index of all the pupils, of the weights of the pupils from the Moose Mountain Reserve giving the weights when they returned from summer holidays and their present weights.

I am free to admit that they do not get the type of food they are used to having on the reservations, I am concerned with providing, as adequately as finances will permit, the type of food that will build good strong bodies and am satisfied that in this we are getting results.

With reference to the training. All the pupils from grade IV to grade VIII inclusive receive training which is fitted as nearly as circumstances will permit to the strength and the ability of the individual child. I have endeavoured as much as possible to cut down the amount of work to be done in order that time may be given to instruction, but as the per capita grant is based upon the presumption that the pupils will do productive work, instruction is frequently crowded out entirely or is reduced to the minimum necessary to get the work done.

I think that perhaps the chief cause of complaint is the fact that I have discontinued the practice of feeding all the folk who come for a visit, three meals a day, for anything from one day to ten days. I was compelled to do this about a year and a half ago when representations were made to me by certain of the parents of our pupils, to the effect that we were expected to use the funds provided to feed the pupils and not visitors. Since that time I have had several inquiries from some of the folk who had been in the habit of paying extended visits and they are always complaining that it used to be done and therefore should be continued.

In closing, may I say that this school is always open to visitors. Parents and relatives are made welcome and facilities are provided for them to visit with their children, entirely free from any supervision or intrusion from any member of our school staff. Either the Matron, Miss Cochrane, or myself make a point of greeting the visitors and arranging for the pupils to meet with them at the earliest opportunity.

With reference to Department letters of the 7th and 18th instants,
File No. 133-0-10 (W T) and File No. 133-0-1 (W T), respectively, in connection
with truancy of Indian children at the Brandon Residential School, and complaint
against Reverend Mr. Strapp, the Principal. I have today been advised by
Mr. W.J.D. Kerley, in answer to request for the information following receipt
of Department letter of the 7th instant, to the effect that Clifford and Verna
Shepherd did attend the St. Francis Day School on the White Bear's Reserve for
about two weeks in September, 1946, but their names were not shown on the school
register.

I have read with interest copy of the report of Mr. A.G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies for Manitoba, following his visit to the Brandon
School to investigate the complaint.

Apparently there is no way to avoid having Clifford Shepherd return
to the White Bear's Reserve, Mr. Strapp having admitted that he is totally unable
to control the boy.

Mr. Hamilton has visited the school and seems to have been satisfied
with Mr. Strapp's action in this and other matters but I am not satisfied that
Clifford Shepherd is a hopeless reprobate.

We have to consider the danger of a boy running away from a residential
school in cold weather and freezing to death on his way to his reserve. This
has happened on more than one occasion, as the Department is aware. We have also
to consider the effect upon some of the other children in the school when a boy can
be discharged from a school simply by giving some trouble to the Principal. Few
children go completely through school without at some time becoming a little dis-
satisfied. Their futures can easily be ruined by giving them encouragement to
endeavour to become discharged as soon as such a feeling arises.

I notice that Mr. Strapp takes exception to the fact that Mr. Kerley took
two affidavits from Indians about statements which they had received from their
children attending the Brandon School. There is a suggestion in Mr. Strapp's letter
that Mr. Kerley went out of his way to have a complaint laid against the Brandon
School. The reverse is more in accordance with facts. Mr. Kerley has had too
much experience in dealing with Indian schools, both day and residential, to
encourage the complaints of Indians against a school. However, he cannot refuse
to listen to a complaint and the mere fact that the matter was taken up with the

Clifford Shepherd,
Reference your 209-11 of January 11.

Copies of your letter and the Reverend Mr. Strapp's letter were sent to Inspector Ostrander. We have now received a reply from him in which he concurs in your recommendation that Mr. Strapp be instructed to return Clifford to his home.

Therefore the Department authorizes the discharge of this pupil from the Brandon Residential School. You are to notify the Reverend Mr. Strapp of this decision and inform him that he is to carefully explain the following to Clifford Shepherd:

(a) that he is being discharged on the understanding that he is to attend the day school on the White Bear Reserve,

(b) that if his attendance there is not satisfactory, this fact will be reported to the Department for further action.

This information is being passed to Inspector Ostrander so that he can instruct Indian Agent Kerley to check carefully on this boy's day school attendance. It is our intention to send this boy to another Residential School if his attendance is unsatisfactory.

The Reverend Mr. Strapp seems to misunderstand

........... the reasons
the reasons for sending Clifford to his school. Inspector Ostrander's comments are as follows:

"I notice that Mr. Strapp takes exception to the fact that Mr. Kerley took two affidavits from Indians about statements which they had received from their children attending the Brandon School. There is a suggestion in Mr. Strapp's letter that Mr. Kerley went out of his way to have a complaint laid against the Brandon School. The reverse is more in accordance with facts. Mr. Kerley has had too much experience in dealing with Indian schools, both day and residential, to encourage the complaints of Indians against a school. However, he cannot refuse to listen to a complaint and the mere fact that the matter was taken up with the Honourable T. C. Douglas over Mr. Kerley's head would indicate that the Indians were not under the impression that they had Mr. Kerley's support in their quarrel with the school. I am sure Mr. Strapp could see this point of view if he would as carefully consider the whole matter as he seems to have considered the matter of the affidavits. No attempt would have been made to keep the Shepherd children in a residential school if their home conditions on the reserve were suitable but they are not. Please refer to the last paragraph of my letter of October 9, 1946, File No. 1688-303-11B, in this connection.

I note that an error was made in referring to the boy in the third paragraph of the same letter as John Shepherd where he should have been referred to as Clifford. It now seems evident that because of the fact that Mr. Strapp is unable to keep Clifford in his school it will be necessary for the boy to live in a small house in contact with a tubercular mother and we can only hope that he is fortunate enough that he does not contract the disease."

"I am sure that the Honourable T. C. Douglas would agree that a small house with a Tubercular mother and several small children is not an ideal situation. This is one of the cases where I believe that the residential school gives its best service in relieving a sick mother of some of the work of the..."
home and removing healthy children from daily contact with a tubercular person in a small house. If children from houses of this kind are not justifiably placed in residential schools whether the father is willing or unwilling, then I believe we have little excuse for continuing to operate residential schools".

We have your letter of the 27th ultimo with reference to the girls who have decided not to proceed to the Brandon School for higher education.

Referring to Mr. Phelan's letter of May 22nd, file 133-0-10 (E.l), with respect to transportation for John and Gordon Bottle, I wish to advise that John Bottle was transferred to the Brandon Indian Residential School and sent with an escort due to the fact that he was a bad influence on the pupils at the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School where he had been enrolled previously. He was one of the ring leaders in the truancy epidemics and it was felt that it would be best for all concerned if he was removed to another school, such as Brandon, where he could not easily run away. This was done with the parents consent and the approval of the principal of the Sioux Lookout School. We also made previous arrangements with the principal at the Brandon School, but unfortunately neglected to inform you of our plans.

Gordon Bottle was sent to the Fort William Sanatorium in accordance with Dr. Bell's instructions and Mr. Eady was engaged to go as escort in both cases. He is not one of our employees.

I wish to give you a further explanation with reference to my telegram requesting that I be allowed to bring pupils from Island Lake by air to Lac du Bonnett for the Brandon Residential School.

As requested in your telegram of Sept 18th, I might say that I will not be able to get application forms completed for these children unless they are brought out to Norway House for chest X-Ray and further examination by Dr Corrigan. It has been arranged through Dr Wood's office in Winnipeg that these children can be examined on arrival at Brandon and if they are not fit for school they can be put in hospital there for treatment.

Regarding the necessity for sending them to Brandon, I would point out that unless they go to Residential School they will not be able to attend school at all. The parents of ten of the children are going out on the trap lines and the children will have to go with them. It is not possible for them to stay on the reserve during the winter as they have no houses there while they do have cabins on the trap lines. The parents of three others are working at Lingman Lake mine site where there is no school and the father of another boy has T.B. and unable to work. The Priest is keeping the entire family at his Mission on the Reserve until other arrangements can be made for them.

After considering the above, the Department can authorize the chartering of a plane as requested, I would suggest a telegram be sent to that effect so that these children can be removed to school before they leave for winter homes on the trap lines.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of 23rd inst., file 576-10 (EL) we are always having considerable trouble with pupils going to and coming home from Brandon Residential School. To our knowledge no definite arrangements are made in ample time before children are sent home.

Last July when we were on our treaty payments, we found the five pupils from Brandon stranded, so had to make arrangements to get these children home.

On reading over Mr. Strapp's letter he states that he will not send the children home for the holiday period until money is received for the passage. This is probably the reason you presume that Mr. Strapp means the children are going home for Christmas. In his letter he refers to the two months, July and August, summer holiday. Due to the length of trip, children never go home for Christmas.

The following is a list of points that might help prevent a recurrence of delays:

(1) The children have been put on wrong trains, from Brandon which requires a 2 day stop over at The Pas. There is only one train going to Wabowden which will make connections.

(a) The children should take a Monday train from Brandon, arriving The Pas Tuesday morning, leaving The Pas for Wabowden Tuesday afternoon and arriving Wabowden late Tuesday evening. When returning to school they should take a Tuesday train at Wabowden, arrive The Pas Wednesday morning, and leave The Pas Wednesday evening for Brandon, arriving Brandon Thursday.

(2) Notification to parents should be sent out about a month in advance, as the trip from Nelson House is long with 22 portages. Mail is flown into Nelson House only when weather permits.

(3) Ample lunch should be given pupils, the trip is at least 3 days by train, and we have had to supplement lunches here.

We trust this is the information desired.

Your obedient servant,

E. Law,
Supt. Indian Agency.

Re File 578-10 (EL), Jan. 4th, 1949.

Replying to your above letter Florence and Priscilla
Little Chief are daughters of Gordon Little Chief. These
children were sent to Brandon at their fathers request as
he has been in poor health for some time and his condition
is not improving. For weeks at a time he is unable to
work and has had several hemorrhages lately. At present he
is waiting for a call from Dr. Simes for admission to the
Indian Hospital at Fort Qu'Appelle. To safeguard their
health as well as the economic conditions of the family these
girls are better off in a residential school and I would
recommend that their admission to the Brandon Residential
school be approved.

Audrey Nahbixie is the daughter of Charles Nahbixie.
This man is destitute. He is on rations by authority of
Dr. Boyd owing to his very poor health. In view of this
I would recommend that this girl's admission to the Brandon
Residential School be also approved.

W.J.D. Kerley,
Superintendent.

Mr. G. Swartman,
Supt. of Indian Agency,
Sioux Lookout, Ontario.

We are in receipt of an application for the admission of Roy Binguis to the Brandon Indian Residential School.

It is noted that this boy is only five years of age and both parents are living. Is there any special reason why he should receive institutional care and if so why should he be admitted to the Brandon Residential School rather than the Sioux Lookout School?

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, Ottawa

I wish to acknowledge Mr. Phelan's letter of May 4 with respect to the admission of Roy Binguis, #154 Frenchman's Head Band, to the Brandon Indian Residential School.

This boy was admitted to the school at the request of his father who is a graduate of the same school. At the time of his admission the parents were separated and the Sioux Lookout School was already overcrowded. Even if there had been room in the Sioux Lookout School Binguis would not have consented to his admission there. There are already three other members from this family in the Brandon School which is, no doubt, another good reason why the father wished the child to be admitted to that particular school.

G. Sharpe
Superintendent
Sioux Lookout Agency
MEMORANDUM

Colonel Neary
Supt. of Education

Please note attached report from the Royal Canadian Mounted Police concerning the accidental death of Roderick Beardy at the Indian Residential School, Brandon, Manitoba.

Your consideration of this case is invited with a view to any preventive action that might be taken against a repetition of occurrences of this kind at this or other schools.

There is no actual legal question involved, but it seems to me that great care should be taken by the residential school authorities to see that young boys are not exposed to accidents through operating machinery of this kind.

I assume that the Principal of the Brandon Indian Residential School is the same Mr. O. B. Strapp, whom I met on several occasions at the Mount Elgin School.

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Secretary.

August 24th, 1949.

Rev. H.L. Richardson,
Free Christian Mission Fellowship,
Portage la Prairie, Manitoba.

Dear Mr. Richardson:

I acknowledge receipt of your letter of August 17th regarding the proposal to transfer the children of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Sandy and Mr. and Mrs. John Sandy to the Brandon Indian Residential School.

As you are aware, the Brandon School is conducted under the auspices of the United Church of Canada, and the most recent Departmental records indicate that the heads of the families concerned are adherent of the Roman Catholic Church. Until they make a statutory declaration of any change in their denominational affiliations, they are for the purposes of the Indian Act, considered to be of the religious denomination previously indicated, and transfer of their children to a school conducted under different auspices cannot be considered.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education
