Runaway Indian Boys.

1. During the course of other police duties in the Minota Dist., Man.; in the p.m. of the above date, information was received that three young Indian boys had been seen in the district in the p.m. of the 25-8-49, seeking employment.

2. In view of the possibility of boys being the subject of Brandon Radio Station CFHB broadcast of the 25-8-49, Item #639, further enquiries were made by the writer and the captioned noted boy was located working for one, John Smith, farmer, Rural Municipality of Minota.

3. Ross was questioned as to the whereabouts of the 3 boys who had left Indian Residential School, Brandon, Man.; with him on the 25-8-49. At this time Ross stated that Victor Bruce had caught a freight train west, shortly after leaving the school, and Wesley Humble and Job White were working on farms in the Minota Dist., Man.

4. In view of the information supplied by Ross, further enquiries were made & Job White was located working for one Fred Bowles in the Virden Dist., Man.; Wesley Humble was located on the farm of L. Brent in the Minota Dist., Man.

5. Brandon Sub-Division was contacted & requested to make arrangements with Indian Residential School, Brandon, Man.; to have the Indian Boys picked up, by authorities from that point, at Virden, Man., as no facilities were available for detaining subjects at Minota or Hamiota, Man.

Patrol then continued to Virden, Man.; at which point Indian Boys were handed over to R.C.O., i.e. Virden Detachment and subsequently picked up in p.m. same date by O.S. Strapp, principal of Indian Residential School, Brandon, Man.

1. Relative to the above, this a.m., a telephone call was received at this office from J.R. Morrison, Agency Assistant, White Bear Indian Reserve, Carlyle District, Sask., to the effect that the parents of the above named pupils of the Brandon Indian Residential School, Brandon, Man., Allie and Mrs. Nokohoot of the White Bear Indian Reserve, Carlyle District, Sask., had refused to let their above named children return to the Brandon School. They were then residing with their parents at their home on this Reserve and have been since school terminated last June.

2. Mr. Morrison stated that he had taken this matter up with the Indian Agent, Kerle, Broadview, Sask., and that he had received instructions to the effect that if the parents of these two girls refused to allow their children to proceed to the Brandon School, assistance of this Force was to be asked to see that they proceeded to the Brandon School.

3. This same a.m., whilst on other police duties on this Reserve, I called on the Nokohoot family with Mr. Morrison. It was ascertained that the school van was coming to this Reserve to pick up the children for the Brandon School about noon on the following day. Both Mr. Morrison and myself attempted to persuade Allie and Mrs. Nokohoot to allow the girls to proceed to the school by this van, but they refused to do so, stating that they wished to keep the girls at home and allow them to go to school in this Reserve. They were advised by Mr. Morrison that they could make application for this later and if they could show that they could properly look after the children at home, it was quite possible that the children may be allowed to return to their home on the Reserve and attend school here, but at present it was compulsory for the two girls to attend the school at Brandon.

4. These children first went to the Brandon School last winter when it was established that they were not being properly looked after at home. Mrs. Nokohoot periodically leaves her husband, taking her children with her and moving in with other Indians. It was ascertained that she had again only just returned home after leaving her husband, but she denied this, stating that she had been home for some time. November 14, 1949.

Dear Col. Neary;

I have had considerable trouble with about a dozen boys this fall who are persistent truants. Nothing seems to satisfy them in school and unfortunately they keep the other boys always in a turmoil with their coming and going.

Mr. R.S. Davis seems to have the idea that the boys are not to blame but that the principal and staff are at fault. He refuses to even try to see the point that these boys do not like to be in school simply because the organization of school life is so different from the care free life of the reservation during the summer months.

We have over 150 children who do not run away and it seems a pity to have them continually upset by the trouble makers.

I have informed Mr. Davis that I will not make any more long trips to bring these repeaters back to school and I do not want #615 Victor Bruce, Cross Lake and 648 Job White, God's Lake returned to school as their promises not to run away are not of any value. At present they are in the Detention Home at Winnipeg after being picked up by the Winnipeg City Police.

This is not a matter of attempting to please a few boys who are determined not to go to school but is definitely now a matter of protecting the other children against their influence.

Yours truly,

My dear Mr. Hamilton,

When I was at Long Plain School last week I was surprised to observe the presence of four older children in Grades Five and Seven. The excuse for their presence in this junior-grade school is that by the time they were ready to return to Portage La Prairie Residential School, that school was full up and could not receive them.

I later inquired whether Principal McLean could take them in after Christmas but he will not have room.

Then I asked Rev. Principal Strapp whether he can accommodate them after Christmas, and he said that very likely he might be able to.

I have discussed these pupils with Mr. Russell in your office and he assures me that they are not the girls (one is a boy) who caused all that commotion at Portage last year.

You will appreciate my apprehension that they will just be wasting their time in a school where all the other pupils are in the first three grades, with the school being conducted by an uncertificated teacher who is unused to the upper grades, and who ought to be concentrating on the juniors. A proper start in school is so important.

May I request you, therefore, to follow up this matter with the Rev. Mr. Strapp, as Brandon has become "the nearest available school" for these children. Their parents have contributed to bringing this situation into being through their failure, accidental or deliberate, to return their children to the school that they should have been attending. There is, of course, a responsibility imposed on us as Departmental officials to co-operate in securing the prompt return of residential school pupils, a subject that was dealt with in a circular last year, but I have met people who either openly announced that they were "not in favour of residential schools" or whose attitude was obvious from their indifference to the Principal's problem. It is not just a matter of getting the full quota of "grant-earning pupils". It is more important that the same pupils return year after year to receive the proper conditioning.

Some of our workers and associates seem to overlook this factor. Maybe you have an assistant or two whose other duties are so onerous that they leave him little energy to "chase after" pupils who are avoiding school. Unless these men are required to be more energetic in regard to their functions as attendance-enforcers, the good teachers and schools cannot function at anything like full potential or efficiency, and after each vacation the situation will worsen.

There is a Christmas vacation to be faced soon. I trust that there will be more pressure exerted in certain areas to endure the prompt return of pupils to Portage and Brandon. At this time there will not be the excuse that they were picking potatoes in the U.S.A.
This matter of children working for wages when they ought to be in school is one that even the provincial schools find troublesome, but they are overcoming it, and, no doubt, so shall we with the aid of well-considered adjustments and compromises. But in the case of the four pupils who prompted this letter (before "four" becomes "fourteen" and maybe "forty") I think that further compromises ought not to be made. They have been going through the motions of attending school and qualifying their parents for family allowances. The books which they should be using have not been ordered until recently because their attendance was not anticipated, and quite properly not. My opinion (my superiors at Ottawa may order otherwise) is that these four pupils should be directed to report to Brandon after the vacation on the day appointed. Their movement should be assisted and expedited by all those concerned to the fullest extent proper and possible. Any resulting truancy should entail the suspension of allowances.

When the books that were ordered for them are received, they might with advantage be sent (if such action is authorized) to the school which receives these pupils, i.e., Brandon.

The net result of our efforts in this case will be, I hope, a demonstration that we intend not to let the caprice of a few people interfere with the progress of the majority of the pupils.

Yours most sincerely,

C.A.F. Clark
Educational Survey Officer

Memorandum:

SUPERINTENDENT OF EDUCATION

Admission of God's Lake Children to Residential School

This is the first intimation that I have had that admission was refused last year to these children. It appears that the applications must have been held back either by the Superintendent or the Regional Supervisor.

If the parents are anxious to send their children to school at such a distance I do not see any reason why we should oppose their admission as long as accommodation can be found. You have seen a report of the social worker to the effect that the God's Lake Mine School now has few Indians in attendance because of the change in location of fishing camps. I scarcely expect that the Reverend Mr. Gibson would recommend the admission of children who can attend the new school at God's Lake to residential school.

Economics may compel a drastic revision of the way of life and a redistribution of population in the Norway House, Island Lake, God's Lake and Oxford Lake bands. The rising generation may have to follow occupations different from those of their predecessors.

I suggest that inquiry be directed to the local Superintendent as to his reasons for not forwarding the applications to Ottawa. The comments of the Regional Supervisor might also be obtained.

The "nearest available" school is not very near!

My dear Mr. Gibson:

You may already have heard from the Reverend Dr. Dorsey of your Church that he is going to explore the possibility of getting a contingent of residential school pupils from Manitoba to complete the enrolment at Edmonton Residential School.

I do not wish to seem to anticipate action by the proper Church authorities in this matter. You will understand that my official interest is to get adequate schooling for the maximum number of Indian children with the minimum of expense to the tax-payers and the least possible difficulty to the religious denominations involved. Another reason for writing you in this matter is that I had marked the file containing your letter of April 19, 1950 for further attention today after returning from places west of Manitoba.

Reference to your copy of that letter will show you that therein you nominated 23 children for admission to a residential school. At that time you had in mind the school at Brandon. It may turn out now that you will be among those whom Dr. Dorsey will request to find pupils for Edmonton.

It seems to me that in finding these pupils we ought to try to give the Principal who will receive them as early notice as possible all the information possible regarding the educational condition of the child. In regard to the
23 pupils mentioned in your letter I note that you have given information concerning the number of years (or months) that the child has been in school. May I suggest that if possible you add one more item - an indication of the child's competency in English. This may help the Reverend Principal at Edmonton to plan the organization of his classes and may serve to indicate the need for different teaching methods and supplies.

Subject always to Dr. Dorey's instructions, it seems to me that it would be helpful for those concerned to receive a compilation of prospective pupils showing the name, age, sex, treaty number, previous schooling and competency in English. The Departmental officials, through whose offices the formal applications for admission should pass, will probably wish to review such compilations so as to ensure that we are not robbing any Day schools of pupils who can and ought to attend them.

As I do not know what mail service you are getting now, nor the date when a doctor might be available this summer to examine any prospective pupils, I am enclosing a number of application blanks which have to be completed (in duplicate) on both sides before the form is submitted to the concerned Agent for his recommendation. I gather from your letter that you have assisted in the preparation of these forms on previous occasions. As these children have a long journey in prospect, any irregularities in the admission procedure would be a cause of regret.

If it is any comfort to you in attempting the task of persuading parents to permit their children to travel so far, may I say that we have pupils who make the journey from Churchill and York Factory to Prince Albert; likewise from points in the Yukon to Lesser Slave Lake in Alberta; and again from Northern British Columbia by rail and steamer to schools on Vancouver Island. In your area, I suppose, the
most difficulty would arise in getting the children to the railway. I assume that this would be a matter of planned plans-loads and I understand that your missionaries have had plenty of practice in coping with such arrangements.

May I extend my wishes for success in this venture. I regret that I can give it only momentary attention as there are situations elsewhere that are equally demanding.

Yours most sincerely,

C.A.F. Clark,
Educational Survey Officer.

Dear Colonel Neary:

Re: Attendance of Children at Residential Schools

Following my telephone conversation, I am now writing at greater length concerning the whole problem of education on Northern Manitoba Reserves.

May I say that we subscribe fully to the Department policy of establishing day schools and desire to co-operate to the fullest extent. Nevertheless, it is recognized by everyone that especially in Northern Manitoba there are many children who will never get an adequate education unless there is a residential school to which they may be sent.

One of the points which requires immediate attention is a report from our Missionary at God's Lake that pressure is being brought to bear on the Indians who have children at Brandon to have these brought back so that they may attend the day schools. My conviction is that if there were good reasons last year why the children should have gone to Brandon, the same reasons should operate to keep them there now. I am sure we may expect the support of the Department.

In a further letter the Missionary says that there is some difficulty in regard to the proper examination of the pupils. He quotes a letter from Mr. Clark, giving certain instructions about filling in forms, etc. He then goes on to say that most of these applications have been in the hands of the Indian Agent for a year and none for less than four months. In the letter our Missionary says that as he was typing the letter Mr. Gowans brought thirteen applications which had been sent to Mr. Staunton at the first of April. Nothing seems to have been done to complete these applications.

Why do these applications lie in an office for four months and then when we want these children to go to a residential school, we are faced with a lot of requirements -- all of which are necessary -- which will take time and may preclude the possibility of these children being admitted to a residential school?

The Missionary says:

"I had forgotten just exactly what applications had been sent in April but upon examination we found that there was not a single family represented which would send children to the schools on the Reserve. Each family, with the exception of a widow, Effie McKay, headed out to trapping and fishing camps at the East end of God's Lake (one long..."
day's journey from the nearest school at the Mine) and to Kakepehigatic and Grassy Narrows (trapping grounds beyond God's Lake in the bush and two long days' journey from the nearest school at the Mine). Effie McKay leads a precarious existence parking in the homes of her several brothers at times in different locations at the East End or Grassy Narrows and the rest of the time operating a bawdy house at the Mine.

Mr. Gowans, who formerly was with the Hudson's Bay Co. and a manager here at God's Lake Narrows, understood the situation and agreed that these children had no other means than residential school of obtaining their schooling. Mr. Waite was noncommittal and no promises of help were made. They say that they will see us before they leave on Saturday, so possibly we can get something definite from them re what will be done with these applications and what action they will take re sending out the children. Mr. Waite felt that the Indian Dept. would not pay the return fare of the children from Edmonton next summer, but I assured him that you had information to the contrary."

With regard to paying the return fare of these children at the end of the year, it is obvious that Mr. Waite is simply giving the official's version. The Department has promised differently.

Here is a quotation from the Missionary at Oxford House:

"We have four promising children that parents desire to send to boarding school. Mr. Staunton told parents he would rather they would attend school here. So I don't know if they will be permitted to go or not. The parents are of necessity out trapping a good part of the winter and children are away from school. I intend to see Dr. Best when I go to the city next week and see if arrangements can be made for them."

I have a further letter from Dr. Best re children at Gross Lake, from which I quote as follows:

"Mr. T.A. Pollock in a recent letter writes that the parents of the children whose names follow, would like to have them attend Residential School in Edmonton:

George Gilbert Paupanakis, born Feb. 8/43.
Wm. Paupanakis - 9 years old, now attending R.C. School
Allan Paupanakis - 11 years old now attending R.C. School.
(The father is George Paupanakis - a Protestant, but wife is Catholic and evidently Wm. and Allan were baptized by Catholic priest.)
Morris McKay - age 13 - now attending R.C. School
Lillian McKay - age 16 -
Christie Ann McKay - age 19 - attended Norway House Res. School now wants to get full education.

There are two other younger children attending R.C. School though both parents Samuel McKay and wife are Protestant.

Ila Monias - age 15 - attended Norway House - now attending R.C.School.
Jean Monias - age 21 - attended Norway House, was in Grade 8; wishes to get further education."
Dr. Best has pointed out that there is not much chance of Christie Ann McKay or Jean Monias being allowed to go to a residential school.

Memorandum to:

THE DIRECTOR

I am passing Dr. Dorey's letter to you for information. Most of the items have been clarified in correspondence on other files. However, I particularly want you to note the points raised on the foot of page 3 and the top of page 4. I feel that the Minister's office should be informed that the building of the Norway House Residential School should receive priority over the building of Amos, Thunderchild and any other previously mentioned schools.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.
Dear Dr. Dorey:

Attendance of Children at Residential Schools

I have passed to the Director your letter of August 21 concerning the attendance of children at residential schools.

I particularly wanted him to note the remarks with regard to the need for an immediate replacement of the residential school at Norway House. Our Chief Engineer has been requested to start his architects on this design and I hope that the plans will be ready to show you in January or February.

I believe that Mr. Davis is now taking action to send some of these children to your residential schools. I wired him yesterday authorizing the sending of ten children to the Portage la Prairie school and hope that Mr. Strapp has been able to accept other children at Brandon.

I concur with your conclusion that this difficulty will recur every summer until a residential school is again erected at Norway House.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

We have been advised that Shirley, Matilda and Benn Mallett of the Fisher River Reserve were accepted as pupils at the Brandon Residential School without first consulting the Indian Superintendent, Mr. Nield.

Re: Your File 127/25-2-576 May 3, 1950, addressed to Mr. J. D. Minnis,
Supt., Norway House Agency.

Dear Sir:

With reference to the above,

This letter was not received by the Norway House Agency until June 10th, due to lack of mailing facilities during the Spring break-up. It was then forwarded to this Agency arriving today's date.

On my recent visit to God's Lake I was informed by the Chief of the band that the Rev. Gibson had been putting considerable pressure on the parents of the children concerned to get their consent to the children going to Residential School; in fact he threatened them with suspension of Family Allowance according to the Chief's Statement.

Unfortunately, the Rev. Gibson was away during my visit and I was unable to take the matter up with him.

Personally, I can see no reason for the majority of these children attending Residential School when there is a total of three day schools in the Band area. Two of the schools, one U.C. and one R.C. are right on the reserve, the other one is 18 miles away at the God's Lake Mine site where a few of the band reside.

God's Lake is a large reserve and it is true some of the families may be some distance from a school, however, I am sure some arrangement can be made if necessary to enable the children to stay with relations in the vicinity of the school.

I will be at God's Lake on July 3rd, for Treaty payments and I intend to go into this matter very thoroughly at that time.

-over-

Indian Affairs, (RG 10, Volume 6259, file 576-10, part 17)
As regards the applications that were submitted by the Rev. Gibson for 1949, you will perhaps remember he did not have the children examined by the doctor and consequently it was of no use submitting the application forms to Ottawa without the doctor's signature.

The Dept. has spent thousands of dollars on a new U.C. School on the reserve and is at present spending a few more thousands on a new R.C. School, also on the reserve.

It appears to me that every effort should be made to have the children attend the local Indian Day School.

You can rest assured this will be done, a report will be submitted to your office immediately after I have investigated the whole matter.

Your obedient servant,

J. H. Staunton,
Supt., Indian Agency.

In my opinion these children should not be encouraged to go to Boarding Schools when we are supplying day schools in the vicinity. October 2, 1950.

Dear Col. Neary;

Re the above mentioned children; I have questioned Mr. Haggerty who was the driver of our school bus which brought these children down from Hodgson, and he informs me that he visited the office of the Indian Supt. on the morning of Sept. 26th. and made inquiries as to what children were coming to Brandon. The Supt. had just left and the clerk in charge was not able to give any information. As the father assured Mr. Haggerty that he had made application through the office they were brought down to school.

A physical examination has been carried out by our Medical Supt. The Wasserman test is NEGATIVE. The two girls have a vaginal discharge the nature of which could not at the time be determined and so they were admitted to hospital. I am informed by Dr. Duggan by whom they have been treated that the tests made are all negative. Because of the fact that there may have been an infection they have been held in hospital and given routine treatment and will be discharged October 5th. from hospital.

Yours truly,

In the matter of: Change of Religious Affiliation

To Wit:

John Sandy and Mrs. Alma Sandy

of the Pipestone Indian Reservation in the Municipality of Pipestone, Manitoba

Do solemnly declare that we each of us, and both of us, have renounced our adherence and our allegiance to the Roman Catholic Church, and we, both of us, have been baptized and immersed in the name of the Trinity so that we are now members of Churches of Christ (Protestants). Dear Sir:

Last summer & fall we experienced great difficulty in sending out a number of children to the Brandon Residential School. Most of the applications had been forwarded to the Supt. of Nelson River Agency by April in the hope that with this advance information he would be sure to make all necessary arrangements for the children. As this was not done, I have made enquiries of Mr. Gowans in an endeavour to discover the reason why there was delay. Mr. Gowans mentioned that one possible reason was that there are several letters on record stating that force was being applied on the parents to have the children sent to school. I may be able to receive further details re this from Mr. Staunton whom I am writing but in the meantime I would like you to know that there was never any type of compulsion used to obtain pupils for residential school. The actual situation was this that the parents were inconvenienced a great deal in waiting the fall of 1949 for the children to go out to school. Two of these applicants were sent then to Cross Lake Residential School in 1950 because we were held up in the forwarding of the children to the school. We never have & never will send out children to the residential school against the wishes of the parents.

There will be a number of additional applications for residential school and I will see that these are in the hands of the Indian Superintendent in April at the latest. We still have quite a number of children who receive no education due to being located at trapping camps several days journey away from here. These will be the ones who apply for Residential School. As each year there are more permanent homes being built on the Reserve our day school population has ever reason to increase. At the moment there are a large number of beginners due to start here.

Enclosed please find a copy of a letter written to Mr. R.S. Davis, Regional Supervisor in Winnipeg. Mrs. Gosbee, teacher of the United Church Indian Day School, has informed us that she has sent in her resignation and therefore I am applying for the position of teacher of the school for the unfinished portion of the school term. I trust that you will look upon this application with favor. I am arranging my church work so that my undivided attention can be given to the work of the school. Formerly I had gone out to Winnipeg in June but I will forgo that this year.

Yours very truly,

Howard B. Gibson.

February 14, 1951.

Re: Clarence Thomas, Level 2 Technical,
Brandon Collegiate.

Dear Mr. Neild;

I regret to inform you that it has become necessary to discharge Clarence Thomas from this school.

Clarence has given a great deal of trouble during this last few months and I cannot permit him to remain any longer as a pupil in residence in this school.

I have talked to Clarence on several occasions and he has always promised to do better but unfortunately it does not last very long. I have received complaints that he was mistreating smaller boys and taking their spending money from them. I have investigated these complaints and find that they are correct.

This afternoon about 3:15 I received a telephone call from the Principal of the Brandon Collegiate. Mr. Bell informed me that he had had some trouble with Clarence and that he was suspending him from all classes, and it would be necessary for Clarence to present an apology and signify his desire to resume classes before he would lift the suspension.

Upon his return from Collegiate this afternoon, Clarence informed me that he had decided that as he was only causing trouble at school he had decided to leave. I informed him that I had made arrangements for him to return to Hodgson by bus on Thursday.

I remain,

Yours truly,

Principal.

I am enclosing herewith a copy of a letter I have received from Rev. O.B. Strapp, Principal of the Brandon Indian Residential School, regarding the above noted pupil, who was enrolled at his school.

Apparently, Mr. Strapp has discharged this boy from school and I would like to know if it is the policy of the Department to allow principals to discharge pupils of their own free will, without first taking the matter up with me or the Department direct.

In my opinion this man is a little too high handed and while he claims the boy was uncontrollable, it is my belief that a lot of the trouble in this school is not the pupils, but the principal.

I would be pleased if you would take this matter up with Mr. Strapp, and find out just what this boy did and why we were not notified before he was sent home. I feel it is time the Rev. Strapp was put in his place.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Brandon Residential School -
Transportation of Pupils

The children in junior and senior high school grades attending this Residential School are attending classes at the Brandon Collegiate Institute. There are now 38 of these pupils and up to the present they have been transported in a converted school truck. The Manitoba Public Utility Board will no longer grant a licence for this vehicle and it is necessary to immediately make other arrangements for the transportation of these children.

The Principal and the local Superintendent have contacted all firms in Brandon who are operating school buses. A summary of their findings is attached to this memorandum as flag One.

You will note that only one firm is prepared to quote, namely Manitoba Motor Transit Limited at the standard minimum rate of $15.00 per bus return to the school.

I would recommend that the Minister approve the acceptance of this only tender for the transportation of these children.

Director.

4.
